form.definition: noun F or f is the sixth letter of the English alphabet.
noun In music, F is the fourth note in the scale of C major.
noun A fable is a story that teaches some moral about life. It frequently has animals as characters. ...a fable about greed.
noun Fabric is cloth made from cotton, wool, silk, synthetics or other fibres which are woven or knitted together. ...three metres of fabric. ...fabric cushion covers.
noun The fabric of a society is the system of ideas and views which the people of the community share and which holds them together. ...a threat to the fabric of civilization.
verb If you fabricate a story, an explanation or a report, you invent it. What you say is not true. It turned out that he'd fabricated the whole story in order to gain sympathy.
adjective In informal language, when you say that something is fabulous, you mean that you think it is wonderful. You've found a job? Fabulous! We had a fabulous time. She's a fabulous teacher.
noun The facade of a building is the outer wall that you can see from the street. ...the historic facade of the town hall.

noun If you put up a facade, you behave in a particular way in order to deceive people about what you are really like or how you are really feeling. When I lost my job, I put on a facade of cheerfulness so that my family wouldn't see how desperate I was. Behind that cynical facade he's a lonely man.
noun Your face is the front of your head with your forehead, eyes, nose and mouth. At the bottom of your face is your chin. He'd been punched in the face.
form.note: ... SEE THE PICTUREat body.b noun Your face is also the expression that other people can see when looking at you. They greeted us with smiling faces. Don't make such a miserable face. Her face became angry.

form.definition: noun A face is also the front or side surface of something. ...a clock face. They were perched on a sheer cliff face. He climbed the eastern face of the mountain.

verb If you face something or someone, your front is turned towards them. How could anyone build a house in the Australian tropics with all the windows facing north? I'd prefer to sit facing the door.

verb If you face someone who worries or scares you for some reason, you meet or talk to them. Greg finally faced his boss to ask whether he would be retrenched. I can't face Rolf any moreI feel so bad about not helping him.

verb If you face a problem or something unpleasant, you find yourself in a situation where you have to do something about it. We must face the fact that the business is in real trouble. I can't face doing the washing up tonight. The closure means that thousands more will be facing unemployment.

verb When someone faces you with something, they confront you with it by talking to you about it or showing it to you. You have to do something about the problem or the people involved. The reporter faced the local MP with the latest poll resultshis voters didn't want him any more.

face down or face up If you lie face down or something is face down, the front is lying on a surface so that you can see the back part. If you lie face up or something is face up, the back is lying on a surface so that you can see the front part. The body was floating face up. She laid out the exam papers face down.
face value If you take something or accept something at face value, you believe what you see, hear or observe. Don't accept everything Raoul says at face valuebetter ask a few other people as well.

in the face of If you do something in the face of a difficult situation, you try to deal with it, although things are not easy for you. Carlotta always keeps her cool, even in the face of her boss's obstructive tactics.
let's face it You say let's face it when you are speaking of something which you don't like thinking about. Let's face it, we're all going to be old one day.

make or pull a face If you make or pull a face, you put an amusing, ugly or rude expression on your face. Look at those silly boys making faces at each other! The driver made a rude gesture and pulled a face at me as he overtook.

on the face of it You use on the face of it to refer to the way that a situation appears to be. It may really be quite different. On the face of it Stephen's idea was marvellous, but it just didn't work out in practice.

put on a brave face If you put on a brave face, you try not to show that you are sad or afraid of something. Poor Laurella was trying to put on a brave face when she was wheeled off to the operating theatre.
to someone's face If you say something to someone's face, you say it directly to them. Michaela won't say to my face that I work too slowly, but she goes round the office telling everyone else.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective facial ...facial features. ...facial hair.

form.definition: adjective Someone you describe as faceless is a member of an organisation or government agency who makes decisions which affect people but who remains anonymous. One of those faceless bureaucrats decided to cut my benefits.

noun A facelift is a cosmetic operation in which a plastic surgeon cuts the skin around someone's face, pulls it up and stitches it together again. This can make your face look thinner and makes your wrinkles disappear.

noun You also use facelift to describe improving the appearance of a place such as a building or an area of ground. I see your offices have had a facelift. We've decided to give the kitchen a facelift with a new coat of paint.
noun A facet is one of the aspects or parts of something such as an organisation, structure, idea or plan. You need to understand the various facets of the company before you start working here.
noun A facet is one of the small, polished surfaces of a precious stone.

verb In formal language, you say you facilitate something when you make it possible or easier. An additional lane on the highway should facilitate access to the northern suburbs. This seminar aims to facilitate the participation of women in ethnic organisations.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun facilitation

form.definition: noun A facility is anything that makes your life or job easier in some way. Facilities are things like buildings, organisations or machines. The resort has a wide range of facilities, from tennis courts to fully equipped offices. This photocopier has a facility to enlarge or reduce the image.
noun Facility is also the ease with which you can do something that needs a certain skill. Sandy's facility in expressing herself is amazing in a three-year-old.
facilities When you refer to the facilities of a building, you mean the toilet and bathroom. A similar word is amenities.
noun A facsimile is an exact copy of something such as a book or other written text. The latest book on Henry Lawson's poetry includes facsimiles of his early manuscripts.

noun A fact is a piece of information about something that exists or that has happened. Facts are based on truth. Just give me the facts, not what you think about it. The report gives many interesting facts and statistics.
noun Fact is also used to refer back to something that you have just talked about. The situation here has become progressively worseyou can't deny the fact.

as a matter of fact In spoken language, as a matter of fact is used to emphasise what you are saying or to introduce a new and sometimes surprising idea. You usually start the sentence with it. Obesity can kill. As a matter of fact, it is one of today's most serious health problems. 'I don't suppose you've finished yet?' 'As a matter of fact, I have.'

in fact or in actual fact If you say in fact, or in actual fact, you want to stress what you are saying, or extend what you have already said. I don't like her much, in fact I really loathe her. He looks quite old, but in fact he's only fifty. In actual fact, I've already been waiting for an hour.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See factual.

form.definition: noun A faction is a group within an organisation or party who share the same ideas and aims. Their ideas may not be the same as those of other members of the organisation. Conflict between left and right factions has been a consistent theme in the party's history.

noun A factor is a single idea, fact or aspect having some effect in a situation. Smoking is a major factor in heart disease. I left because of several factors, but poor pay was the main one. Time, cost and quality are the factors we have to consider.
noun In mathematics, a factor is a number which is multiplied by another factor to give the product. The numbers 3 and 5 are factors of 15. Costs have increased by a factor of ten.
noun A factory is a building or a group of buildings where goods are made or mass-produced by people using machines. He works in a car factory.

factory floor The factory floor is the area in a factory where you find the machines and the people who work with them. This area is distinct from the offices. Carol was promoted from the factory floor to a sales position.

adjective Something is factual if it refers to events, situations or things that really exist. Factual writing does not include anything about feelings or imagination. Please give a strictly factual account. The report contained several factual errors.
noun A faculty is a department or a group of related departments within a university or large school. ...the Arts Faculty. ...the Faculty of Engineering. ...a meeting for all members of the faculty.

noun Your faculties are your mental powers. They are your ability to do things such as think, speak, reason and remember. Robert's faculties were so seriously affected by the accident that he had to re-learn everything, even speaking.
noun A fad is an idea or a fashion that a lot of people follow, usually only for a short time. Do you remember the fad for flared trousers?
verb If a colour or material or a piece of clothing fades, the colour becomes less bright, often because of being in the sun. The curtains on the western side of the house have faded badly.
verb If a light or a bright image fades, it slowly becomes less bright, and turns dark. What I miss most about Europe are those long summer evenings when the daylight slowly fades.
verb If something fades, it becomes weaker or disappears. The sound of the engine faded into the distance. His strength was beginning to fade. Her anger faded in the face of his distress.
verb If someone's health or life fades or fades away, they are very sick and become steadily weaker until they die. I'm afraid she's fading fast. It was terrible to watch him fade away.

fade in or fade out This is a technical phrase used in sound and film recording. When sound or picture fades in, the sound slowly becomes louder and the picture becomes brighter. When sound and image fade out, they gradually disappear.

noun Faeces is the body waste which leaves your body through the anus. This word is used in formal or medical language; the word shit has the same meaning in informal language, but it can offend some people.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this is feces.

form.definition: noun In informal language, a fag is a cigarette. I'm dying for a faghave you got any?

dictionary.entry: Fahrenheit`fAr@nha:It noun Fahrenheit is an older scale for measuring temperature which is still used in some countries. In this scale, the melting point of ice is 32 degrees above zero (32;dgF), and the boiling point of water is 212 degrees above zero (212;dgF). ... COMPAREthis with Celsius, which is the modern scale for measuring temperature. ... NOTEIn written language, you will probably see a ;dg, but in spoken language we say 'degree'.

form.definition: verb If you fail to do something, you don't do it although you are expected or supposed to do it. Some people have still failed to return their forms. That's the second appointment she's failed to keep.
verb If you fail someone, you don't do what you should do for them. This government has failed the country completely. If I drop out of university I'll be failing my parents.

verb If you fail as something or in a duty you have to perform, you have not been successful in doing it. I sometimes think I've failed as a parent. It would be failing in your responsibilities to ignore the matter.
verb If you fail something such as an examination or a test, you do not succeed in it. The opposite of this is pass. Kris has failed her maths test.
verb If someone fails you in an examination or a test, they decide that you don't have the level of skills necessary to pass it. I hate having to fail any of my students.

verb If a machine or a piece of equipment fails, it doesn't work properly or it stops working altogether. The brakes suddenly failed and I couldn't stop the car. If the power fails, the emergency electricity is generated.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See failure.adjective failed ...a failed attempt. ...a failed actor.

form.definition: noun A failing is a part of someone's character or of a plan that is not as good as the rest of it or as it ought to be. You're too impatient, that's your main failing. A serious failing in the report was its lack of detail about costs.

preposition If you are going to do something failing something else, you plan on doing it ifthe other thing doesn't happen. First we'll trythe existing bore. Failing that, we'll have to cartwater into the settlement. Ask Sue or, failing her, Tony.
noun Something that you try to do but are not able to achieve is called a failure. The operation was a failureJim's sight has not improved. What have been your main successes and failures?
noun A failure is also someone who doesn't do what they very much wanted to do or were expected to do. When I gave up the diet I felt a complete failure.

noun If there is a failure in something such as a piece of equipment, it isn't working properly or it stops working. We'd better stock up on candlesI bet we'll have at least one power failure this winter.
verb If you faint, you start feeling dizzy and may even lose consciousness. He fainted from the shock.
adjective If something is faint, it is not strong or intense. You can only see a faint outline of the building through the haze. The echo here is rather faint. She gave a faint smile.
adjective If skin or hair is fair, it is a light colour. Kylie's hair has become much fairer over the holidays.
adjective If something is fair, it is at an acceptable standard. It is not good or excellent. Mario's examination results were fairnothing special, I'm afraid.

adjective If you are fair, you treat people in a right and just way. You do not give special favours to anyone. As a teacher, you must be fair to every student. Do you think that a one-year sentence for drink-driving is fair? I'm only asking for a fair hearing.

adjective If a sports match or a game is fair, the players follow the rules of the game. The state-of-origin match this year was one of the fairest matches I've seen for a whilehardly any kicking or hitting at all.
adjective If the weather is fair, there is little or no cloud and the sun is shining. It's been fair all day so far. Let's hope tomorrow will be fair.
noun A fair is an event where there are a lot of stalls selling food, clothes, plants and other things. There are also games or amusements where people try to win prizes. Let's go to the street fair.

noun A fair is also a large meeting of buyers and sellers of products of a particular type. Fairs often take place regularly and attract people from many different countries. Other words for this are exhibition and show.

fair dinkum In informal language, you use fair dinkum to show your surprise, and to question whether something is true (if your voice goes up) or else to emphasise that something is true (if your voice goes down). 'Ahmed's won a house in Queensland.' 'Fair dinkum?' 'Yes, fair dinkum.'
fair game Someone is said to be fair game if they are weaker in some way than other people who treat them badly. Paul is fair game for all the school bullies because he never hits back.

fair go In informal language, a fair go is a chance or opportunity to do something or get something. People in small business need to be given a fair go. You often say fair go when you want to be given a chance or when you think you are being treated unfairly. 'Finished the cleaning up yet?' 'Fair go, mate! I've only got one pair of hands.'
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb See fairly.noun fairness In all fairness, I can't blame him for being angry. ...treat all students with fairness.

form.definition: adverb If something is fairly good, bad or difficult, it is quite good, bad or difficult, but not very. That's a fairly difficult task. I've always been a fairly happy person. The weather was fairly good.
adverb Fairly is also used to say that something is done in a just and right way. We must divide the money up fairly.
noun On a golf course, the fairway is the area of grass between the tees and the putting area.
noun A fairy is an imaginary creature with magical powers found in children's stories and fairytales.
noun In informal language, fairy is an offensive word for a male homosexual.
noun Fairy bread is buttered bread covered with tiny brightly-coloured balls of sugar called hundreds and thousands. It is often eaten at children's parties.
noun Fairy floss is sugar spun in a special machine so that it looks like coloured cotton wool. It is wound onto a stick and eaten.

noun A fairytale is a traditional story in which there are creatures with magical powers, such as fairies, and animals that can talk. ...a book of fairytales. The castle looked like something out of a fairytale.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective fairytale They had a fairytale wedding.

form.definition: noun Faith is the confidence or trust you have in someone and in what they do. I have complete faith in Carla's ability to run the department.
noun Someone's faith is the religion they follow. It is their religious belief. Followers of many different faiths have worshipped here.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See faithful.

form.definition: adjective If you are faithful to a belief or cause, or to a person, you are firm in your support. You do not change your mind and abandon them. Even faithful Labor voters are beginning to doubt. Celia has always been a faithful friend to me. His dog was a faithful companion on these walks.
If you are faithful to your husband, wife or lover, you don't have sex with anyone else. He was faithful throughout the time they were apart.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb faithfully Yours faithfully, Roy Read.

form.definition: verb If you fake something, you pretend that something is the case although, in fact, it is not. Manuel faked an asthma attack so that he could take a sickie. She faked her mother's signature on the report card.

noun A fake is something that is designed to make you think that it is something else, usually something more expensive or valuable. It is not what it seems to be. Those paintings turned out to be fakes.
adjective If something is fake, it is false or not genuine. She frowned with fake concentration. The walls are lined with fake marble.
verb If something falls, it moves through the air, from a higher to a lower point. The book fell off the shelf. Be careful you don't fall out of the window!
verb If someone falls, they move from an upright position to the ground, often accidentally. I started to feel dizzy, fell to the floor, and after that I can't remember anything. He tripped and fell.

verb If you say that things such as prices, standards or levels fall, you mean that they have dropped or become lower. Petrol prices have fallen again. A lot of parents think that education standards are falling.

verb You also use fall in certain phrases to say that you pass into a different condition or state. I can't remember how often Katsumo has fallen in love already. Dad, don't fall asleep when you're reading me a story! Has Nadya fallen ill again?
verb If something that is long falls, it hangs down from a higher level. She has auburn hair falling to the waist. Cascades of flowers fell from the balcony.
verb If something falls on a particular day, it happens on that day. Christmas Day falls on a Sunday this year. If two exams fall on the same day, it may be possible to move one of them.

verb If a government or a country falls, it loses its political power. A government falls when it loses an election; a country falls when it is beaten in war by another country. It seemed certain that the Labor government would fall in the 1993 electionsbut surprisingly, they won. Saigon eventually fell to the communist Viet Cong.
fall apart If something falls apart, it breaks into pieces or is destroyed in some way. This house is falling apart around me. When Sinead left her husband, his life fell apart.
fall back on If you fall back on something, you use it when another thing has been unsuccessful. If you can't get the toaster to work, you can always fall back on the grill.

fall flat If something falls flat, it doesn't have the effect you thought it would have. You use it when people don't understand a joke or they don't laugh at a joke which you thought was very funny. All my stories fell completely flat. Her rousing speech fell flat with the audience.
fall for
(a) If you fall for what someone says, you believe them when they try to deceive you or trick you. I completely fell for his lies.
(b) If you fall for someone, you fall in love with them. I really think she's falling for you.

fall off the back of a truck In informal language, if you say that something has fallen off the back of a truck, you mean that it has been stolen. I wouldn't buy that radio from himI reckon it's fallen off the back of a truck.
fall out with If you fall out with someone, you have an argument or quarrel with them. She fell out with her brother and they didn't speak for ten years.

fall over backwards If you fall over backwards to do something, you do far more for someone than people usually do. There we were, falling over backwards to help Aziza settle in her new home and she didn't say thank you once.

fall short If something falls short, it is not good for a particular purpose or you don't have enough of it. There should be enough bread, but we just may fall short. I must admit that the movie fell short of my expectations.
fall through If something falls through, it doesn't happen, even though you had expected it to. Our trip to Thailand fell through at the last moment. I thought I'd get the job, but it fell through.
noun A fallacy is an idea which many people believe to be true, but which in fact is not true. It is a common fallacy that all women want to have children.
adjective Someone is fallible if they can make errors or mistakes. Don't worry about itwe're all fallible.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun fallibility

form.definition: noun Fallout is small particles of dust, soot or radioactive particles in the air resulting from a nuclear explosion or a volcanic eruption.
adjective If something is false, it is not true or correct. He gave a false statement to the police. She had made false entries in the accounts.
adjective If something is false, it is intended to look like something else but is only a copy of it. ...a ring set with false diamonds. ...a set of false teeth.

under false pretences If you do something under false pretences, you pretend you are something you are not in order to take advantage of a situation. He got into the house under false pretences, by claiming to be a police officer.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb falsify

form.definition: verb If you falter, you are no longer certain whether you should do something that you have planned or decided on. When she got to the end of the diving board, she faltered. Don't falter now, it's your big chance.
verb If something falters, it becomes less intense and may even disappear. At the approach of his older brother, Haziz's voice faltered.

noun Fame is when a lot of people know who you are and recognise your face, or when the media report about you. It was this film that really shot him to fame. Grace enjoys quite a bit of local fameshe saved a child from drowning last year.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See famous.

form.definition: adjective If someone or something is familiar to you, you know them quite well or you recognise them. I'm sorryyour face seems so familiar but I can't remember your name. The street looks familiarI must have been here before.

familiar with If you are familiar with something, you know it well. I'm quite familiar with Japanese history but I don't know anything about the language. Jenny has only just started working here so she is not yet familiar with office procedures.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb familiarise (<or> familiarize) noun familiarisation (<or> familiarization)

dictionary.entry:
family`fAm@li:, `fAmli:families 1a noun Your family is the people that you are related to. Your immediate family is your father, mother, brothers and sisters. If you marry, your immediate family becomes your husband or wife
Your extended family is all the people you are related to. It includes your grandparents, aunts, uncles, cousins, nephews and nieces.
noun In biology, a family refers to species of plants or animals which are related.

form.definition: noun Family allowance is a fortnightly payment by the Department of Social Security to help with the costs of bringing up children. The amount paid depends on the parents' combined income and is usually paid to the mother.

noun Family allowance supplement is a fortnightly payment by the Department of Social Security to help with the costs of bringing up children. Any families whose income is below set limits can apply for it.
noun Family law is the area of law that applies to parents and their children. It governs separation and divorce as well as custody, access and guardianship of children.

noun If a couple practise family planning, they use contraception to make sure that the female partner becomes pregnant only when they want to have children. The Family Planning Association gives information to people about this.
noun A family room is a room where members of a family relax and do things such as watch television and play games.
noun A famine is a period when people don't have enough food to eat, for example because there hasn't been enough rain to make their crops grow.
adjective In informal language, if you say that you are famished, you mean that you are very hungry. What's for supper? I'm famished.
adjective If someone or something is famous, a lot of people know about them. ...a famous film star. What's she famous for?
noun A fan is someone who likes a pop star or movie star very much. They collect information about them and go to all their concerts or films. His latest album has disappointed many fans.

noun A fan is a device which moves air around in order to keep things cool. Traditional fans are made of paper, leaves or cloth. Modern fans are made of plastic or metal and are driven by an electric motor.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb fan (fans, fanned, fanning) I fanned myself with the newspaper.

form.definition: noun A fanatic is someone who believes so much in a particular idea that they won't accept any other views. Amy is a real diet fanaticyou can't convince her that a normal, well-balanced diet is best.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective fanatical Sean is a fanatical jogger.

form.definition: noun A fanbelt is the part of a car that drives the cooling fan.
adjective If you say that something is fanciful, you mean that it is exaggerated and not really true. He told some fanciful story about why he was late.
verb If you fancy something, you want or like it very much. I really fancy a nice plate of vegetables. I think Ildiko fancies Tom quite a bit.
noun A fancy is a strong desire or liking for something or someone. Tonight I've got a fancy for something spicy. I think she's taken quite a fancy to you.
verb If you fancy that something is the case, you are reasonably sure that it is. I fancy I can see a light through the windows.
verb If you fancy yourself, you imagine yourself to be something that you really aren't. Robert fancies himself a top business executive, but he can't even handle the family finances.

adjective If something is fancy, it is richly decorated, often at great expense. They live in a really fancy house with huge rooms and expensive furniture. Her dress was covered with fancy bows and lace. I don't want any fancy food, just a good, plain steak.
fancy dress If you wear fancy dress, you wear clothes that make you look like a different type of person. Everyone's wearing fancy dress for Yani's partyI'm going as a pirate.
fancy that In informal language, you say fancy that to show surprise. 'Nerida has just moved back in with her parents.' 'Fancy that! She only moved out last weekthat didn't last long.'
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See fanciful.

form.definition: noun A fang is one of the long, sharp teeth of a snake which it uses to inject venom.
noun The fangs of a wolf or a dog are the canine teeth near the front of its mouth. Blood was dripping from the creature's fangs.
noun In informal language, you use the word fangs to refer to any of your teeth. Come on, guys, get your fangs into this!

adjective In informal language, when you say that something is fantastic, you mean that you like it very much or are very pleased about it. We had a fantastic time last night. Yoshi's been promotedisn't that fantastic?

adjective You say something is fantastic if it is in some way greater than normal or than you expect it to be. Cormack paid a fantastic price for that old clock. Some of these turtles can reach a fantastic age.

adjective You also say something is fantastic if it is strange, unbelievable or seems as though it cannot be real. She told me this fantastic story about how she was kidnapped by aliens. He's always coming up with some fantastic scheme or other.

noun A fantasy is a picture or an idea that exists in your mind and is unlikely to happen or exist. Young children find it hard to distinguish between fact and fantasy. I've got a fantasy of giving up my job and going round the world.

dictionary.entry:
farfa: (adjective and adverb forms farther or furtherfarthest\minion0\or\optima0\furthest
adverb If something is far away from you, it is a long distance from where you are. My house isn't far from the school. How far is it from Perth to Sydney? Our stop's not much further now. I was standing further back from the stage than you.
adjective A far place is one that is a long distance away. Pam's moving to the far north of Queensland. On the horizon lay the far mountains.
adverb If an event is far away in time, it happened a long time ago or will happen at some stage in the future. Think far back to your earliest memories. 'When are you getting married?' 'Oh, I don't know yet; that's too far off.'
adverb Far is also used to refer to the degree or the extent to which something exceeds something else, and can often be used instead of much. My sister's far older than me. It'll take far longer to do it that way. She's had far less to drink than me. That made it far worse.
adjective The far side or edge of something is the one that is more distant from where you are. You can also say 'the other'; the opposite is this. That tall guy on the far side of the room is my brother. There's a great fishing spot on the far bank of the river. It went straight through and out the far side.
a far cry from If something is a far cry from something else, it is very different from it, and usually much better or worse. The five-star hotel was a far cry from the dingy hostels of my student days.
as far as (a) You use as far as to say that you have reached a certain point in time or place. This is as far as I got with my enquiries. The old bomb made it as far as Mareeba in North Queensland. (b) You can also use as far as or so far as to indicate that what you say relates only to someone or something mentioned. As far as I'm concerned, you may as well throw it away. He's still coming, as far as I know. As far as colour goes, I'd prefer red.
by far If something is better, more beautiful and so on than something else by far, it is much more so. That looks much tidier by far. Karen is by far the best boss I've ever worked for.
far and near If people come from far and near, they travel long distances to get somewhere. Crowds poured in from far and near.
far gone In informal language, you say someone is far gone when they have reached an advanced state of a condition or an illness. After ten glasses of wine, Andre was too far gone to drive a car. I'm sorry to have to tell you this but your friend is pretty far gonewe don't expect her to live out the week.
far out In informal language, you say something is far out when it is very unusual or amazing. You sometimes use it to show surprise at what someone has said. 'Norita's just gone on a year's trip around the world.' 'Far out!' He comes up with some pretty far out ideas. She was wearing a really far out dress with snakes printed on it.
so far So far means 'until now'. There haven't been any problems so far. That's my best result so far. How's your new job going?' 'So far, so good.'

form.definition: noun A farce is a situation that is supposed to be serious and important but develops so that one or more of the people in it look foolish. The meeting was an absolute farce. They made a complete farce of the whole process by appointing someone who hadn't even applied.
noun A farce is a humorous play or film where people get into very complicated and funny situations. His latest film is a good-natured farce. ... WORD FAMILYadjective farcical What a farcical result!
noun Your fare is the money you pay for a ticket on transport like a bus, train or plane. I just had enough money for the taxi fare. We offer the best fares to all destinations.
verb In rather old-fashioned language, if you say you fare well or badly, you experience something good or bad. Women have traditionally fared badly in the workplace. I hope to fare better next time.
noun In literary language, people say farewell when they leave each other and do not expect to meet again for a long time, or at all.
adjective You say something is far-fetched if it seems exaggerated or unlikely. Some of her arguments are distinctly far-fetched. He's got some far-fetched plan to sail round the world.

dictionary.entry: farmfa:m noun A farm is a small business that grows vegetables or other crops and raises animals such as cows, pigs or chickens for profit. Manuel has just bought a tobacco farm near Cairns. She's planning to start an emu farm. ... A SIMILAR WORDis station. A station is much larger than a farm and raises thousands of sheep or cattle. Some stations extend over thousands of hectares. ... WORD FAMILYverb farm Robert farms wheat. The family has farmed for generations.noun farmer I've been a farmer all my life.

form.definition: adjective Something is far-reaching if it is going to have an effect on a lot of people or their way of life. The new tax regulations will have far-reaching consequences for the small business sector.
adjective If you arefar-sighted, you are able to think well ahead when you make plans or decisions. Your plans are not restricted just to the present and a little time ahead.
verb In informal language, you say someone farts when they pass wind from their anus. To do this in public is considered rude and offensive in Australia.
adjective Farther is the comparative form of far.

dictionary.entry: fascinate`fAs@nEIt verb If something fascinates you, it is very interesting and you can hardly stop thinking about it. All those glittering lights on the Christmas tree fascinated little Anuka. I've always been fascinated by history. ... WORD FAMILYadjective fascinating He wrote a fascinating account of his discoveries.noun fascination I watched with fascination as the strange figures came nearer.

fashion`fAS@n 1a noun Fashion is the style of clothing that is popular for a period of time. High-heeled shoes are back in fashion. She always wears
noun Fashion is also generally the style of doing things, making things or behaving that is popular at a particular time. Fashion dictates what sort of music trendy people listen to these days. Is colonial furniture in fashion or should we all have glass and metal?
noun In fairly formal language, you use fashion to mean the way you behave in a particular situation. Lotte talked in a very agitated fashionshe must have been quite upset.
... WORD FAMILYadjective fashionable Stand-up collars were fashionable in the '70s.adverb fashionably He's always very fashionably dressed.

fastfa:st(\minion0\adjectiveandadverbforms\optima0\fasterfastest 1a adverb If you do something fast, you do it in a relatively short time. Michael reads very fasthe gets through a book every day. You have to be able to think pretty fast if you want to go on 'Sale
adjective If you are fast, you do something in a relatively short time. You need to be fast around hereotherwise, all the food will be gone. That was fastI though it'd take you a week.
adverb If you move fast, your individual body movements follow each other quickly. They were dancing faster and faster.
adjective If you are fast, you have quick body movements. You need to be fast in karate to surprise your opponent.
adjective If the colour in a material is fast, it doesn't disappear or fade when the material is washed. Sometimes the dye in these cheap T-shirts isn't fast.
verb If you fast, you don't eat any food for a certain period of time, often for religious reasons. During Ramadan, we fast from sunrise to sunset.
noun A fast is a period of time during which you don't eat any food. I went on a 40-hour fast for World Vision.
adjective Fast money is money you earn in a fairly short time, often without working for it very hard. If you want to make a fast dollar, go and work on an oil rig for a while. There's some fast money in that job, if you play your cards right.

form.definition: verb If you fasten something, you fix it firmly in place by joining it to something else. Don't forget to fasten your seatbelt. I fastened the sheets together with a paper clip. The jacket fastens with a single button.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun fastener The paper clip served as a fastener for all his loose notes.

form.definition: noun Fast food is hot food such as hamburgers, pies, and fried chicken that is served to you very soon after you order it, usually because it is prepared in advance.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective fast-food ...a fast-food shop.

form.definition: noun Fat is the white-yellowish substance under the skin and within the muscles of animals and people. A good beef steak should have thin layers of fat in it. I'm putting on too much weight and need to lose some fat.

noun Fat is also any solid greasy substance. Many fats derived from animals and plants are used in cooking. Butter and margarine are fats. Too much fat in your diet is unhealthy. Add some fat to the frying pan.
adjective If you are fat, your body shape is plump or round because of the fat in your body. I've been getting really fat lately.
adjective If something is fat, it is thick. He produced a fat bundle of banknotes. I've still got three fat books to read.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective fatty (fattier, fattiest) ...fatty foods.verb fatten They fatten the cattle for sale.

form.definition: adjective If something is fatal, it is so serious or dangerous that it causes someone's death. Viv was involved in a fatal accident. The bite of the redback spider can be fatal.

adjective In informal language, if you say something is fatal, you mean that it has bad or serious results. Mentioning football was fatalhe'll keep going all evening now. My fatal mistake was adding too much cheese to the sauce.

adjective If you are fatalistic, you believe that you can do little to influence what happens to you, as everything is controlled by fate. At first I was worried about the result, but now I'm quite fatalistic about it all.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun fatalism

form.definition: noun A fatality is when a person is killed in an accident or by violence. There have been three fatalities on that corner this year.

noun A fat cat is an informal expression for someone who holds a special or high position in industry or the public service. They enjoy a lot of special privileges because of this. All the fat cats came to the meeting in their fancy cars.
noun Fate is an outside force that some people believe determines what happens in your life. Fate has meant us to meet.

noun Your fate is also your future, which is determined by outside forces. They set out to sea, not knowing what their fate would be. The driver didn't stop after the accident, but left the victim to his fate.
noun Your father is your male parent.
verb In formal language, you say a man fathers a child when he becomes a father.

fathers In rather literary language, fathers refers to members of your family or community who lived long ago and are remembered for their part in your family or community history. Our fathers worked themselves to the bone trying to make a living from the land.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See paternal. adjective fatherly Let me give you some fatherly advice.

form.definition: noun Your father-in-law is the father of your husband or wife.
noun Fatigue is the state of being tired and exhausted. Fatigue is common during pregnancy. After the race I felt extreme fatigue.

noun In technical language, fatigue is a weakness in the structure of certain materials which leads to them breaking or falling apart. The cause of the aeroplane's crash was found to be metal fatigue in the wing section.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective fatigued

form.definition: noun In informal and rather insulting language, someone may be called fatso if they are fat. Watch where you're going, fatso!

noun A fault is a mistake or error that you make. Marks will be deducted for each fault. I'm sorry about the delayit's all my fault. It's not my fault the dinner's ruined. She's a bit impatient, but we all have our faults.

noun If there is a fault in a material, there is something wrong with it. It may be broken or cracked, have a hole, and so on. There must be a fault somewhere in the wiring. The blinkers just won't turn off. This dress is reduced because of a fault in the pattern.
find fault with If you find fault with someone, you are very critical of them. The teacher seems to find fault with Corinna all the time.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective faulty The fire started because of faulty wiring.

form.definition: noun In biology, fauna are all animals seen as one group. The native fauna of Australia are unique in the world.
form.note: ... NOTEFlora are all plants seen as one group.

form.definition: noun A favour is something you do for someone else to help them, although you don't have to do it. Thanks, Greta. You really did me a favour there. Could I ask you a favour, would you get me some bread while you're at the shops?
noun A favour is also a preference for someone or something, for which there may not be a good reason. I don't want favours just because I'm the boss's daughterI want to be judged on my own merits.

noun A favour is a small present for children who go to another child's birthday party. 4a in favour If someone is in favour of a plan or an idea, they support it. They prefer it to other plans that are put forward. Everyone at the meeting was in favour of going ahead. There were seven votes in favour and three against.
If somebody rules in favour of you, they have made a decision that you are right in a dispute or disagreement. The magistrate in the Family Law Court ruled in favour of the wife.

out of favour If someone or something is out of favour they are not generally liked. They are not popular although they may have been before. The team has been out of favour with the general public since the foul play incident.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this word is favor. ... WORD FAMILYverb favour I certainly favour Mark's plan.

form.definition: adjective If something is favourable, it is good, helpful and supports you and your plans. Given favourable weather, we should be able to sail there in three days.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this word is favorable. ... WORD FAMILYadverb favourably

form.definition: adjective Your favourite book, film or food, or anything else you are comparing, is the one you like more than all the others. Who's your favourite actor? My favourite time of year is the spring. I was wearing my favourite dress.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this word is favorite. ... WORD FAMILYnoun favourite Lime jelly's my favourite. Don't argue with hershe's the boss's favourite.

form.definition: noun A fax is a copy of a letter, document or picture which is sent by electronic means over the telephone system. There were several faxes in my in-tray. Why don't you fax it?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb fax Can you fax a letter for me?

form.definition: verb In informal language, if you say that something doesn't faze you, you mean that you are not worried about it. It doesn't disturb you. Michelle drove from Broome to Perth all by herselfit didn't faze her a bit.[xp \start\[ap--fear

noun Fear is the strong unpleasant feeling that you have when you think someone may harm you or something bad or dangerous may happen. He showed no fear in battle. There was a sense of fear in the village where the murder took place. I really must conquer my fear of flying. He was motivated by a fear of failure.
verb If you fear someone or something, you worry about them because you think they may do you harm. We do not fear the enemy. As a child, I used to fear my father's anger.
verb In formal language, if you say you fear something is the case, you are expressing regret about it. I fear he's a lazy child. It won't be ready today, I fear.

adjective If you are fearful, you are afraid because you think that someone or something is going to harm you. The opposite of this is fearless. People stood around in the streets, fearful of a further earthquake. I was besieged by fearful villagers. Tama has always been a fearful child.
adjective If something is fearful, it causes you to be afraid or alarmed. We were confronted by the fearful sight of the angry mob. I faced the fearful prospect of losing my job.
adjective If something is feasible, it is possible and realistic to do it. The plan seems to be feasible within our budget. Many of the suggestions that people made were not remotely feasible.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun feasibility

form.definition: noun A feast is a meal at which large quantities of especially good food are served, often in celebration of something. We had a real feast for Christmas dinnerchicken and nine types of vegetable. After a month in the bush I was looking forward to a real feast when I got back.

noun You can also call anything that provides large quantities of good things a feast. There's a feast of entertainment in the city over the summer. The decorations in the hall were a real feast for the eyes.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb feast We feasted on prawns and lobsters. Feast your eyes on that, then!

form.definition: noun A feat is a great triumph or success. It was a real feat for Chris to become a lawyer in spite of his blindness. We learnt about the feats of the early explorers. Completing the course was a feat of endurance.[qr

dictionary.entry:
feather`fED@
noun Feathers are what cover the body of a bird.
feather your own nest If you feather your own nest, you make sure that you benefit, especially financially, from a situation instead of acting impartially. Some of the contractors had clearly been feathering their own nest.
... WORD FAMILYadjective feathered adjective feathery

form.definition: noun Your features are all the parts of your face, such as your eyes, nose and mouth. Bin Ba has almost the same features as his sisterexcept that he has a larger nose.

noun A feature of something is a special quality or characteristic that distinguishes it. A special feature of our trip is the chance to go diving for pearls. The hill is a dominant feature of the landscape. The new model has a number of extra features.
noun A feature is an article in a newspaper, magazine or TV program that deals with one particular subject. This week's special feature takes a closer look at women in trades.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb feature The deluxe model features an automatic defrost facility.adjective featured The miniature heater was a featured item in the catalogue.adjective featureless If you're not used to it, the bush seems utterly featureless.

form.definition: abbreviation for February.
noun February is the second month of the year.
verb Fed is the past tense and past participle of feed.

adjective A federal system of government involves a number of partly independent states joined together under a central government with wider powers than the state governments. Decisions about foreign policy are taken at federal level. The Department of Immigration is a federal authority. Canberra is the federal capital of Australia.
form.note: ... ANOTHER EXPRESSIONfor the Australian Federal Government is the Commonwealth Government. ... WORD FAMILYverb See federate.

form.definition: verb If a number of states or countries federate, they join together to form one country with a central government. Each state keeps its own government with a certain degree of power. The Australian states federated in 1901.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun federation

form.definition: noun A fee is the money you pay for a service or for permission to do something. ...a parking fee. ...an entrance fee. ...a membership fee. Fees are payable on application for most classes of visa.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is charge.

form.definition: adjective If someone or something is feeble, they are weak. They do not have much strength. The old woman was too feeble even to dress herself. The troops easily overcame the feeble resistance of the small town. He made a feeble protest, but was overruled.
adjective A feeble explanation, excuse or argument is not very convincing. She told some feeble story about getting stuck in traffic.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb feebly

form.definition: verb If you feed a person or animal, you give them something to eat and sometimes help them to eat it. Babies should be fed whenever they're hungry. Birds feed their young by putting food into their mouths. When all the shearers arrive, there's a big crowd to feed.

In a more general sense, when you talk about feeding people, you mean providing them with enough food. He's got five children to feed and clothe. China has serious problems in feeding its growing population.

verb If you feed something, you provide it with whatever it needs to work properly or function smoothly. When I've finished feeding the data into the computer, we can look at the results. The high school is fed by three local primary schools. You need to keep the printer fed with paper.
verb If a person or animal feeds on something, they eat it. Frogs feed mainly on insects. The baby is feeding at the momentcan you ring back?
noun Feed is food for farm animals. Pets generally eat food, as in cat food and dog food. When you're in town, pick up some feed. Our supplies are pretty low.

noun In informal language, a feed is a meal or something to eat. Look at the size of that steak, mate. Is that a feed or not? I'm looking forward to a good feed tonight. I'm beginning to feel I could do with a feed.

fed up with In informal language, if you say you're fed up with something or someone, you mean that you're bored or annoyed with them and don't want to have anything more to do with them. I'm fed up with you kids always whinging. Everyone gets fed up with their job from time to time.

noun Feedback is information that you give someone, expressing your opinion about something they have said or done. Without feedback from the community, the council cannot work as it should. The author welcomes feedback from her readers so that the next edition can be brought up to date.

verb If you feel something, you touch it with your hands to find out about it. Feel this clothyou can tell it's silk. I felt the parcel eagerly, trying to guess what was inside. The blind girl felt the plant carefully.

verb If you feel for something, you reach for it with your hands without looking or being able to see. Laura felt in her handbag for the keys. 'Where's the remote control gone?' 'Try feeling down the sides of the lounge.'

verb If you feel something, you become aware of it through your senses without being able to see it. The purse must be under the sofaI think I can feel something at the back. I felt a breeze on the back of my neck. He felt a sharp pain. We felt a bump as we ran over the object.
verb If you feel something, you become aware of it although you have no direct knowledge or definite proof. Somehow I felt something had changed between us.

verb If something feels a particular way to you, it makes that impression on you. The clean sheets felt wonderfully crisp. The water felt nice and cool on my feet. There's something about the plan that just doesn't feel right.

verb If you feel a particular way, you experience that state or emotion. I feel sick todayI don't think I can go to work. Do you feel hungry yet? Pat felt really disgusted with Andy for letting her down. I felt really happy when I heard your news.

verb If you feel something, it is your opinion. This is a polite way of saying what you think. Boris feels we should spend Christmas with his family. I feel we need to expand our customer base. There's a danger of missing the deadline, I feel. What do you feel, Ramesh?
feel for If you feel for someone, you pity them and have sympathy with them. I really feel for Nadja, stuck in that tiny flat on the seventh floor.

feel out If you feel out a situation, you try to find out what's happening and what the likely outcome will be. We need to feel out the money situationwhere it's coming from and when. I tried to feel out Anna's attitude to the proposal.

feel your way If you feel your way somewhere, you find your way in the dark by putting out your hands to touch things. I hate it when I have to feel my way to the bathroom at night in a strange house.

You also feel your way when you are in a situation that's not familiar to you, such as a new job. You cautiously try to find out how to deal with it. I'm afraid there are no hard and fast rulesyou have to feel your way through experience.

get the feel of If you get the feel of something, you gradually come to understand it. It'll take you a while to get the feel of how to hold the chisel. I'm beginning to get the feel of how to handle my boss.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See feeler.noun See feeling.adjective See feeling.noun feel I love the feel of silk. She soon got a feel for the job.

form.definition: noun Feelers are long, thin parts of an insect's body that are usually attached to its head. It uses them to find its way or to find out about things around it.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is antenna.

form.definition: A feeling is an awareness of something although you have no direct knowledge or proof of it. I had a sudden feeling that there was someone in the room.
A feeling is an emotional reaction to something. Sometimes you have to follow your feelings, and not logic. I experienced a great feeling of sadness when he left.
A feeling is an opinion, view or belief. The general feeling amongst us is that we should accept the offer.
adjective A feeling person is sensitive to other people's emotions. We need someone more feeling in the role of liaison officer.

gut feeling In informal language, a gut feeling is an idea or thought which you have very strongly but can't explain. I've just got this gut feeling that he's not being straight with us. My gut feeling is that we should go ahead.

mixed feelings If you have mixed feelings about something, you are not sure what to think of it. In some ways it's good and in other ways it's bad. I've got mixed feelings about movingthe job itself is perfect, but it means leaving my family and friends.
noun Feet is the plural of foot.
verb If you feign something, you pretend that you feel it. Gregorio feigned a headache to get out of washing the car. It was difficult to feign enthusiasm for her holiday photos.
verb Fell is the past tense of fall.

noun In informal language, a fellow is a man. In very informal language, this word is sometimes spelt fella. Come on, fellows, let's get on with the job! Just wait till the fellows at the club hear about this!
noun Fellow is also used, particularly by Aboriginal people, to mean any person. Another spelling for this is fella.
adjective Your fellow workers or fellow students are the people you work or study with.
noun A felony is a serious crime, such as murder or burglary. Felonies are tried before a judge andjury.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun felon He is a convicted felon.

form.definition: verb Felt is the past tense and past participle of feel.
noun Felt is a type of cloth made of cotton or wool fibres that are pressed tightly together rather than woven.
noun A female is an animal or plant of the gender that can produce young ones. The male lions bring back food to feed the females and young.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is male.

form.definition: noun Female is a rather offensive term for a woman. He usually has an attractive female on his arm.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective female ...a female koala. That's a typically female point of view!

form.definition: adjective If someone or something is feminine, they have qualities or characteristics which are traditionally supposed to be typical of women. There's something very feminine about his gestures. She put her remark down to feminine intuition, but I think she had inside knowledge.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is masculine.

form.definition: adjective In some languages, certain words and forms, including those relating to women, are called feminine.
noun A feminist is someone who believes that women should have the same rights as men and tries to advance the role of women in society.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun feminism

form.definition: noun A fence is a type of wall made from wood, wire, steel posts or other materials. It separates a block of land in a suburb, or a farm or station in the country, from the land around it.
form.note: ... SEE THE PICTURE at house.b verb If you fence a garden or other area of land, you erect a fence around it. All domestic swimming pools must be securely fenced.

form.definition: verb If you fence in a discussion, you avoid giving direct answers. Under direct questioning by the press, the minister started fencing. You can't fence any longerwhich is it, yes or no?
fenced-in A fenced-in area of land has a fence around it.
If you feel fenced-in, you feel as if you are trapped and there are not many things that you can do. I'd always planned to travel, but now I'm pretty much fenced-in at work.
noun Fencing is a sport in which two people fight each other using long, thin, pointed swords.
noun Fencing is also the materials that are used for making fences.

If you fend for yourself, you find food, shelter, clothing and anything else you need without help from other people. Some of these street kids have had to fend for themselves since they were ten years old. The mother kangaroo carries the joey in her pouch until it is able to fend for itself.

If you fend someone or something off, you manage to prevent them from harming you. The old lady fended off the muggers with her walking stick. Police fended off the blows with riot shields. Sam tried to chat me up, but I fended him off. The cash fended off hunger.
adjective A feral animal is descended from domestic ones but now lives in the wild. Feral camels, horses and donkeys have become a threat to our native flora and fauna.

dictionary.entry:
fermentf@`mEnt for the verb; for the noun,`f@:mEnt
verb If something ferments, it undergoes a chemical reaction under the influence of an organic agent. Wine is the fermented juice of grapes. The dough will rise as the sugar in it ferments.
noun If a situation is in a state of ferment, people are very angry, and there is a possibility of disorder or even violence. The whole office is in a fermenthow dare he get rid of such a loyal worker in that way!

form.definition: adjective If someone or something is ferocious, they behave in a fierce, uncontrolled and savage way. The Cossacks were feared as particularly ferocious fighters. A ferocious guard dog was chained outside. The premier has had to face ferocious criticism. The wind became ferocious.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb ferociously noun ferocity[qr

dictionary.entry:
Ferris wheel`fEr@s wi:l
noun A Ferris wheel is one of the things you can ride on at fairs and amusement parks. It is a huge wheel with seats hanging down from the edge at regular intervals.
... ANOTHER SPELLINGof this is ferris wheel.

form.definition: noun A ferry is a type of boat that transports people and cars from one side of a river, harbour, or other body of water to the other side. The ferry to Mandorah goes twice a day. The load limit for the ferry is fifty persons and five cars.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb ferry (ferries, ferried, ferrying) I'm always having to ferry the kids to and from their friends' houses.

form.definition: adjective If an animal or plant is fertile, it can produce young. Hybrids are often not fertile. Rabbits are extremely fertile and can threaten a population explosion.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is infertile.

form.definition: adjective Fertile land or soil is capable of producing a lot of crops.

adjective If you have a fertile imagination, you have lots of ideas that are often different from the ordinary. Raul's an excellent designerhe's got such a fertile imagination. Peta says she saw an intruder, but she does have a fertile imagination!
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb See fertilisation.

form.definition: noun Fertilisation is the process by which a male's reproductive cell combines with a female's reproductive cell to form a new organism.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this word is fertilization.

form.definition: noun Fertilisation is also the adding of fertiliser to soil.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb fertilise (<or> fertilize)

form.definition: noun A fertiliser is a substance that helps plants grow, such as manure or chemical products. A good organic fertiliser does wonders for your garden and doesn't damage the environment.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this word is fertilizer.

form.definition: adjective If you are a fervent admirer or enemy of something, you have very strong feelings either towards or against it. The Prime Minister is losing the confidence of even his most fervent supporters. She has long been a fervent opponent of environmental destruction.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun fervour (<or> fervor) She spoke with fervour about the need to act.

form.definition: verb If a wound or sore festers, it becomes infected and filled with pus.

verb If a bad thought or idea festers in your mind, you can't forget it and you become embittered. The disappointment festered in her for years. He had been festering for months, and now he was poised to take murderous revenge.
noun A festival is a special celebration, especially one held at a particular time of year to celebrate a religious occasion. The festival of Diwali marks the Hindu new year.

noun A festival is a season of artistic performances and exhibitions. Often it is held regularly every year or every second year. I went to Adelaide for the Festival. They're having a special festival of French films in March.
adjective If something is festive, it is appropriate to a celebration. They'd made the hall look very festive for the party. I was caught up in the festive atmosphere.

verb If something is festooned with something, it has it draped over it. The Christmas tree was festooned with tinsel and fairy lights. The anchor emerged festooned with seaweed. At university he was festooned with prizes and awards.

verb If you fetch something, you go to where it is, collect it and bring it back. Can you go and fetch me a glass of milk, please? I went to fetch a blanket from the bedroom. We'll send a courier to fetch the documents. He taught his dog to fetch a stick.
verb If something fetches a certain price, it is sold for that price. The house could fetch over $3 000 000 at auction. Rare first editions will always fetch good prices.

noun A fete is a special event organised by a school or other community group to raise money. It is a type of fair and usually has stalls selling second-hand and homemade goods, competitions and amusements for children, and raffles. I volunteered to run the cake stall at the annual school fete.
adjective A fetid smell is very strong and offensive, like something rotting.
noun A fetus is an unborn human or animal developing in the womb.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this word is foetus.

form.definition: noun A feud is a long-lasting disagreement or quarrel between people or groups, particularly families. Don't try and interfereit's a family feud that goes back two generations.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb feud They've been feuding over the divorce settlement for a year now.

form.definition: noun A fever is a rise in body temperature above the normal level because of illness. If your child has a fever, make sure that they have plenty of fluids or they can become dehydrated. She's running a slight fever.
noun A fever is an illness of which a major symptom is a raised body temperature. In the days before modern medicine, many children died of fevers before they were five. ...glandular fever.
noun A fever is also a state of high excitement or frenzied activity. In the fever of the wedding preparations, Paola had forgotten to confirm the restaurant booking.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective feverish I wiped her feverish brow. We made feverish preparations for his arrival.

form.definition: determiner Few means 'not many'. These days few people have heard of him. There are few good restaurants in the area. I was homesick for the first few days. He's one of her few friends. b pronoun Few is used to refer to a small number of people or things. Few would fail to be amazed by the sight. Few of the guests bothered to come in costume. Few of the injuries were serious.
2 a few (a) If you have a few things, you have some, but not many. Only a few more days to Christmas! I'll be back in a few weeks. I've had a few problems lately.

(b) A few is also used to refer to an indefinite but small number of people or things. A few of us got together to buy a present for our teacher. There won't be many times when this happens, but there will be a few.
as few as You use as few as to emphasise how low the number of people or things is. As few as twenty workers have accepted the offer. Some people solved the puzzle in as few as three attempts.
few and far between If you say that things are few and far between, you mean that not many of them exist. Traditional record players are few and far between these days.

no fewer than You use no fewer than to emphasise how high the number of people or things is. No fewer than two hundred people crowded into the hall to hear her speak. He has a collection of no fewer than four thousand different beer bottles.

quite a few If you have quite a few things, you have an indefinite but fairly large number of them, more than someone might expect. We've had quite a few complaints about that. Quite a few people turned up for the meeting in spite of the rain. I bet he made quite a few dollars out of the deal![xp\start\[ap--fiance
noun A woman's fiance is the man to whom she is engaged. She has promised to marry him.
noun A man's fiancee is the woman to whom he is engaged. He has promised to marry her.

noun A fiasco is a situation where things go badly wrong, especially because they haven't been properly organised. The whole conference was a fiasco, with no-one knowing where they were supposed to be when.

noun A fib is a lie told by a child, or a minor lie told by an adult. I'm sick of your fibsI'm going to ring the teacher and find out what really happened. I said we'd hung her painting in our bedroom, which was a fib.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb fib (fibs, fibbed, fibbing) No, it's notyou're fibbing! I fibbed that I'd love to meet him again.

form.definition: noun Fibres are thin strands of which a substance is made up. The wool fibres are spun into threads. His cancer was caused by breathing in asbestos fibres.
noun Fibre is the tough tissues contained in plants. The flax stems are left to rot until only the fibre is left. A healthy diet contains plenty of fibre. The mats are made from coconut fibre.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective fibrous

form.definition: noun Fibreglass is a material that contains thin threads of glass. Different types of fibreglass are used to make insulation panels in buildings, car and boat bodies, and curtains and blinds.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective fibreglass ...a fibreglass hull.

form.definition: Fibro is a building material made from pressed sheets of asbestos and cement.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective fibro ...a fibro shed.

form.definition: noun Fiction is a type of prose that does not deal with facts. Authors of fiction create characters and stories from their imagination. I enjoy reading modern Australian fiction. The film sits in an uneasy territory between fact and fiction.

noun A fiction is something that is not true or a situation where people are only pretending something. He maintained the fiction for months before being detected. Every Christmas we play at the fiction of being a happy family enjoying each other's company.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective fictional Who's your favourite fictional character?adjective fictitious He had obtained a passport in a fictitious name.

form.definition: verb If you fiddle with something, you keep handling or touching it. Stop fiddling with that knife or you'll cut yourself. Someone had fiddled with the settings. I fiddled with the lock until eventually it opened.

verb If you fiddle something, you act dishonestly to get more money or some other advantage for yourself. He'd been fiddling his income tax returns for years. She was caught fiddling her expenses. We'll have to fiddle the figures a bit to make the profits look better.
noun A fiddle is a musical instrument shaped like a violin and used in folk music.
fiddle around If you fiddle around with something, you try to fix it or improve it by trying various actions. Nicky spends all his time in the garage fiddling around with that car of his.
fit as a fiddle If you are fit as a fiddle, you are very healthy. Rodney's over eighty, but he's still as fit as a fiddle.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun fiddle He knows every tax fiddle there is.noun fiddler The fiddler played a traditional tune.

form.definition: adjective If something is fiddly, it is difficult to do because it involves fine movements or a lot of different steps. Tying shoelaces is sometimes too fiddly for young children.
noun Fidelity is being faithful to a person or belief.
noun Fidelity is also the degree to which something such as a recording or translation is like the original that it came from. CDs generally give a higher fidelity of sound than records.

verb If you fidget, you move your body restlessly because you are nervous, impatient or bored. Stop fidgeting and sit still! He was fidgeting with a paper clip as he spoke. Don't keep fidgeting with your hairit looks fine as it is.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective fidgety

form.definition: noun A field is an area of land where wheat, vegetables or other crops are grown.

noun A field is a large open area where sports such as soccer, football or rugby can be played. 3 noun A field is an area where a particular force has an effect. There is a strong electric field around power lines. A current is passed through the coil to create a magnetic field.
noun A field is also an area of expertise, knowledge or study. He did research in the field of laser technology. I'm afraid modern history's not my field. Journalism's a very popular field.

noun The field is all the people who are taking part in a race or some other competitive activity. Hy-Min was leading the field as they came into the final straight. We must make sure that our company establishes a clear lead over the rest of the field.

If you work in the field, you do not work in an office or laboratory. You work out of doors or you meet clients or customers in their workplaces or homes. John's a geologist, and he works mainly in the field nowhe loves his regular outback excursions.
verb If a sporting club fields a player, it chooses them to play in a match. Our opponents will be fielding a strong team.

field day If you have a field day, you enjoy yourself enormously and have a lot of fun because of some special circumstances. The mice had a field day when our cat died. The lawyers are going to have a field day with the small print in this contract.
field event A field event is an athletics event that involves throwing something or jumping rather than running. The opposite of this is track event.
field work Field work is work done outside the office or laboratory. Lorna does mainly field work nowshe travels to remote Aboriginal communities to discuss housing needs.
field worker A field worker is someone who works outside the office or laboratory.

adjective If a person or animal is fierce, they are angry or violent. The headmaster can be fierce, but he's very kind. She gave me a fierce look. There was a fierce dog chained up outside. He made a fierce attack on the prime minister.

adjective If something is fierce, it is very strong or intense. A fierce storm raged outside. There was fierce competition for the funding. He felt a fierce love for her. The heat in January can be really fierce.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb fiercely She was fiercely protective of him.

form.definition: adjective If something is fiery, it is very hot or looks like fire. There was a beautiful fiery sunset. Suporn cooked us a really fiery curry. I began to wilt in the fiery heat.

adjective If someone or something is fiery, they are full of strong feelings. She has a fiery personality. The union representative made a fiery speech to the workers. No agreement was reached in the fiery debate.
noun Fifteen is the number 15, ten plus five. We were fifteen at table. You can borrow up to fifteen at once.
adjective If you have fifteen things, the number of things that you have adds up to fifteen. They searched through the fifteen rooms of the old deserted building but found nothing of interest.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See fifteenth.

form.definition: adjective The fifteenth thing is the one that comes in order after the fourteenth. Take down the fifteenth book along.
noun A fifteenth is also one of fifteen equal parts. Her son is not going to be pleased to inherit only a fifteenth of the estateas one of four children, he was expecting to get a quarter.
adjective The fifth thing is the one that comes in order after the fourth. We took fifth place in the competition.
noun A fifth is also one of five equal parts. Twenty percent equals a fifth.
noun Fifty is the number 50, five lots of ten. We're hoping for an attendance of about fifty.
adjective If you have fifty things, the number of things you have adds up to fifty. I can type fifty words a minute now.
fifties The fifties in the twentieth century is from 1950 to 1959, in the nineteenth century from 1850 to 1859, and so on.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective fiftieth

form.definition: abbreviation for figure. The creature gradually changes into a frog (see fig. 17).

verb If you fight, you hit someone with your fists, kick them or use some sort of weapon to attack them. Seth was punished for fighting with other boys. She fought her attackers and drove them off. The documentary showed two male kangaroos fighting. I once saw Mohammed Ali fight.
verb If countries, armies or soldiers fight, they are at war. There were protests against our soldier fighting in Vietnam. My father fought the Japanese in the Second World War.

verb If you fight, you have a quarrel with someone. They fought over the division of the profits. Anna's always fighting with her sisterI can't stand the noise. I've been fighting with the council over the planning consent.
verb When two sporting teams fight, they both try to win a match or game. Casuarina is fighting Palmerston in next Saturday's match.

verb If you fight something or you fight against something, you try to make sure that something bad or dangerous won't happen or become worse. Our aim is to fight discrimination in every form. She's been fighting cancer for several months.

fight a losing battle If you fight a losing battle, you are not successful in what you are trying to do. Doctors seem to be fighting a losing battle against the spread of AIDS. I tried to persuade her, but I was fighting a losing battle.

fight back If you fight back, you resist someone or something. I'm not accepting my dismissal just like thatI'm going to fight back in the courts. She was determined to fight back against her illness.

If you fight back an emotion, you try not to feel it or at least not to express it. I had to fight back my anger when the neighbour's dog dug up my garden. He fought back tears as he described his father's death.

fight for If you fight for something, you try to make sure that something good or beneficial will happen. We must continue to fight for minority rights. I had to fight for my education, so I know how important it is.

fighting chance If you have a fighting chance, you have a reasonable prospect of success although you'll still have to work very hard. With the leader out of the race, we're in with a fighting chance. My teachers reckon I've got a fighting chance of getting a place at college.
fighting fit If you are fighting fit, you are extremely healthy and in a positive mood. 'How are you today?' 'Fighting fit and ready to go.' Steve was soon fighting fit again after the operation.

fight off If you fight off someone or something, you resist them and try to make them run away or disappear. I managed to fight off the mugger. I've been trying to fight off a cold with lots of vitamin C.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun fight noun fighter

form.definition: noun A figment of someone's imagination is something that they have made up. It doesn't really exist. She talks about her boyfriend, but no-one's ever met himI'm beginning to wonder if he's just a figment of her imagination.
noun A figure is a number or the amount represented by it. Think of a figure between 5 and 10. Shona's good at working with figures. The final figure was $4 275. Can you put a figure on the losses?

noun A figure is a person in a picture or scene. You don't know who they are or it isn't important. I could see a figure in the distance. Who's that figure on the left of the photo? The engraving showed a garden with three figures in it. A figure in black came onto the stage.
noun Your figure is the shape of your body. Brenna lost five kilos and she's got a fantastic figure now. These exercises will help to trim your figure.
