noun A figure is someone who is important or serves an important function. Gough Whitlam is one of the key figures in Labor Party history. My aunt was an important figure in my life as a child.
noun A figure is an illustration or diagram in a book. The process is shown in the figure below. The textbook contains many useful figures and tables.

verb In informal language, if you say you figure that something is the case, you mean you think or believe it. I figured there'd be lots of good tucker here, so I came. I figure he's a pretty good dancer.

figure out In informal language, if you say you figure someone or something out, you mean you come to understand them. I still haven't figured out what she meant by the remark. It took me a long time to figure out how to get the lounge through the door. I've got my boss pretty well figured by now.[qr

dictionary.entry:
filefa:Il
noun A file is all the documents and other information about a subject held together in one place. The personnel files are kept in a separate cabinet marked 'Confidential'. I made a note of the matter in her file. I've started a separate file for the conference preparations.
noun A file is a folder or box for keeping documents and papers in. We need ten more files to organise all this stuff.
noun A computer file is a set of data which the computer can access together under one name.
verb If you file something, you put it away with all the other documents relating to the same subject. The letters are filed in date order. File each invoice under the customer's name. Her desk was piled high with papers waiting to be filed.
verb If you file something such as an application or complaint, you submit it officially. You must file your claim within 30 days of the damage occurring. Marietta has filed for sole custody of her children.
verb If people file somewhere, they walk one behind another in a line. The children reluctantly filed into the room. We were forced to file along the narrow ledge.
noun A file is a flat piece of metal with a rough surface or a piece of wood or cardboard covered with sandpaper. You use it to remove bits of something to make it smoother or smaller or change its shape. ...a nail file.
verb If you file something, you make it smoother or smaller or change its shape using a file. She sat there filing her nails while the customers waited. You need to file away the rough edges.
... WORD FAMILYnoun See filing.

form.definition: adjective In formal language, you call your duties as a daughter or son your filial duties.[qr

dictionary.entry:
filing`fa:IlIN
noun Filing is putting documents away in the right place so that they can be found again easily. Sonia comes in twice a week to do the filing.
noun Filings are very small pieces of a material that have been removed from a larger piece with a file. ...iron filings.
filing cabinet A filing cabinet is a special type of cupboard with very deep drawers for storing documents in.
filing clerk A filing clerk is someone whose job is to file documents.
filing system A filing system is the way in which documents are stored so that they can be found again easily. We've set up a new filing system for the orders. It took a while to get used to their filing system.

form.definition: adjective If someone or something comes from the Philippines, you can describe them as Filipino.

verb If something fills or you fill something, it becomes full. The space inside it is taken up by something. Fill the saucepan with water. You'd better fill in that hole before someone gets hurt. The stadium began to fill with fans. I filled a whole page with writing.
verb If something fills you with an emotion, it makes you feel that way. Seeing so many homeless children on the streets fills me with anger.
verb If you fill a job or position, you appoint someone to do it. The receptionist vacancy was filled within a week. I'm sorry, we've already filled that post.
verb When a dentist fills a tooth, they remove a patch of decay and replace it with a paste that sets hard. A couple of my back teeth have been filled.
noun Fill is material such as soil, rocks and rubble that you use to put into big holes in the ground. CLEAN FILL WANTED
fill in
(a) If you fill in a form, you write the required information in the blank spaces. Please fill in the personal detailsthe doctor will do the medical history.
(b) If you fill in for someone at work, you do their job while they're away. Can you fill in for Cora next week? She can't teach because she's in hospital.
(c) If you fill someone in, you give them information about something. I asked Larry to fill me in on the background to the meeting.
fill out If you fill out a form, you write the required information in the blank spaces.
fill up If you fill something up or if something fills up, it becomes completely full. Can you fill the tank up, please? The hole was filling up with water.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See filling.

form.definition: noun A fillet is a piece of meat or fish without any bones.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb fillet

form.definition: noun A filling is a place where decay has been removed from your tooth and replaced with a paste that sets hard. Last time I went to the dentist I had to have a couple of fillings. The chewy toffee pulled out one of my fillings.
noun A filling is what is inside something such as a pie, sandwich or cushion. I bought a sponge cake with a cream and jam filling. The filling was beginning to leak out.

adjective If food is filling, it is quite heavy and substantial. You soon feel that you have eaten enough of it. You need a filling breakfast on a cold day like this. Her pancakes were filling, to say the least!
noun A film is a thin layer of something. A film of dust covered everything in the house. There was a slimy green film on the surface of the water.

noun A photographic film is what you put in your camera to take pictures with. It is a sheet or strip of thin plastic coated in a chemical which reacts to light. I shot three rolls of film at the zoo. I need to buy another film for the party.

noun A film is a strip of pictures which are projected onto a screen in sequence. They follow each other so quickly that you think the people and objects in them are moving. Was this shot on film or video?
noun A film or movie is a story projected in this way. Our teacher showed us a film about the life of a frog.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb film The outdoor scenes were filmed near here.

form.definition: noun A filter is a device that holds back one type of thing and lets another through. Some filters hold back a coarse substance and let a fine one through. Other filters block off part of the light spectrum. The filter in the airconditioner needs cleaning.

If news or information filters somewhere, people gradually learn about it through talking to each other. It filtered out that Salim had been turned down for promotion. There'll be trouble if this filters down to the union. The news took a while to filter through from head office.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb filter Impurities are filtered out of the water.

dictionary.entry:
filthy`fIlTi:filthierfilthiest 1 adjective If something is filthy, it is very dirty. Go and wash your handsthey're absolutely filthy. The family lives in a filthy shack with no running
adjective If something is filthy, it is sexually offensive or pornographic. He told a series of filthy jokes. She gave a filthy laugh.
adjective If something is filthy, it is very bad or unpleasant. Take your filthy hands off me! The weather has been really filthy lately.
... WORD FAMILYnoun filth They live in filth and squalor. I refuse to listen to this filth.[qr

finfIn
noun The fin is the part of the body or tail that a fish uses to control its movement in the water.

form.definition: adjective If something is final, it is the last in a sequence. There are a few surprises in the final chapter. The final episode will be screened next week. I made one final check before setting off. Jones is leading in the final round.

adjective A final result or reply comes at the end of a long process or after a long wait. The council's final refusal of permission meant the end of our plans. His final answer was that he wouldn't be able to attend.
adjective A decision is final when it is not possible to argue or appeal against it. The judge's decision is final. You're not going and that's final!
noun The final is the last match or game in a series. It decides who the overall winner of a contest is. Last year's winner didn't even get into the final this year.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb See finalise.noun See finalist.adverb See finally.noun finality Somehow we find it hard to accept the finality of death.

form.definition: noun The finale is the last part of something like a show, concert or circus performance. In the grand finale, all the dancers whirled around the stage in a dazzling display of colour and music.

verb If you finalise arrangements, you make them definite. You sort out all the details. Have we finalised where the meeting is going to be held? The price has yet to be finalised, but it should be around $20.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this word is finalize.

form.definition: noun A finalist is a person or team who takes part in the final of a contest. The losing finalist is awarded the silver medal. Marina was one of ten finalists out of an initial entry of over 7 000.

If something finally happens, it happens at the end of a long process or after a long wait. Rita finally reached Tennant Creek after a 12-hour drive from Darwin. We've finally paid off the mortgage. Finally he agreed to come. Where has all this finally got us?
You use finally to let your listeners or readers know that you are about to deal with your last point. Finally, I should like to thank everyone who has made today so enjoyable.

noun Finance is all the activities relating to raising, borrowing and investing money. Carlos is taking a degree in economics and hopes to work in the world of finance when he's finished. The paper has a special section on personal finance every Wednesday.
noun Finance is the money needed to fund a project or undertaking. The company simply doesn't have the finance for a project of this size at present. We've arranged the finance for our new house.

verb If you finance a project or undertaking, you provide money so that it can be done. Goodness knows how she's planning to finance university studies on top of all her other commitments! The agency agreed to finance us in return for a share of the profits.
finances Your finances are your money and personal money matters. My finances are a bit low at the moment. I really need to sort out my finances and put some cash into an investment.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See financial.

form.definition: adjective If something is financial, it relates to money or money matters. Do you read the financial pages of the newspaper? He's got financial problems, I hear. The project was a financial disaster.
adjective If you are financial, you have enough money to pay for the things you need to buy. I'm not financial todaycan I give you the money tomorrow?
financial member A financial member of a club, trade union or political party has paid all their membership fees up to date. Only financial members may vote in the election of officers.
financial year A financial year is the twelve-month period over which money dealings for a business are recorded. In Australia, the financial year is from 31 July to 30 June.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb financially

form.definition: verb If you find something that you have lost, you come across it while searching for it. I found your glasses in the bathroom. Where's Kylie disappeared to? I just can't find her. The missing child was found safe and well at her grandmother's.

verb If you find something that you need, you manage to locate or obtain it. I like that dresswhere did you find it? I don't know how I'll find the money for the trip. I found the address in the phone book. If you break it, you'll have to find me another.

verb If you find something, you discover it unexpectedly. You come across it by chance. 'What a fantastic hotel. How did you find it?' 'I read about it in the local paper.' When Peter drove around the Pilbara he found a deserted mine.

verb If you find that something is the case, you discover or decide it. Scientists have found that smoking causes cancer. I think you'll find that I'm right. The jury found her guilty of murder. The judge found in favour of the plaintiff.

verb If you find something to be a certain way, you experience it like that. I find your language offensiveplease don't swear in front of my children. I find him intensely irritating. 'How did you find your steak?' 'It was very good.'

noun A find is something surprising, pleasant or useful that you discover. The word is usually used this way in informal language. You can make some great finds at the markets. The young actor who plays his daughter is a real find.
find out
(a) If you find out information, you discover it. Natalie found out that Simon had been deceiving her. I need to find out about the building regulations. Ring up and find out when he's coming.

(b) If you find someone out, you discover that they have done something wrong or illegal. The new manager was found out after a yearhe'd been transferring store money to his private account. The teacher found Polly outher brother had done her homework.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun finding Research findings have proved the effectiveness of the drug.

form.definition: adjective If something is fine, it is very good or of very high quality. This cabinet is a very fine piece of work. I am in fine health. This is a fine example of what I mean.
adjective If something is fine, it is good enough or acceptable. Tasha's fine, but I can't stand her brother. If you want to stay here, that's fine, but you must let me know.

adjective If you say that you're fine, you mean that you're in good health and don't have any problems. This is a standard answer when someone asks how you are. 'How are you doing?' 'I'm fine, thanks.' 'How are you going?' 'Fine, and you?' 'How are your parents?' 'They're fine.'
adjective If the weather is fine, it is not raining and usually it's sunny. We've had three fine days this week.

adjective If something is fine, it is made of very thin material and sometimes has a lot of detail. It can easily be broken or damaged. This shampoo is suitable for fine hair. The dinner service is made of fine bone china. The spider weaves a fine web.

adjective If something is fine, it is made up of very small parts. I ran my hand through the fine white sand. 7 adjective If something is fine, it is difficult to see, recognise or understand. There's a fine line between assertiveness and arrogance. Philosophers love to make fine distinctions between concepts.
noun A fine is money that someone has to pay because they have broken a rule or law. The judge set the fine at $500. His driver's licence was cancelled because of unpaid parking fines.
fine arts The fine arts are the visual arts such as painting, drawing and sculpture.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb fine That suits me fine. I'm managing fine now. Fine, I'll pick you up at six.adverb finely The silver box is very finely worked. Chop the vegetables finely.

form.definition: noun Your fingers are the long, thin parts at the end of your hands. When we talk about all our fingers, we usually mean the thumbs as well. See the picture at body. I've hurt my finger. Hold it between your finger and thumb. She counted on her fingers.
noun The fingers of the glove are the parts that are shaped to cover the fingers of your hand.
noun A finger is something long and thin. A finger of land sticks out into the sea. Cut the pastry into fingers. I bought a packet of chocolate fingers. We had fish fingers for lunch.
verb If you finger something, you touch it with your hands and make it dirty. Don't finger the biscuits and put them back on the plate! The book jacket had been badly fingered.
finger food Finger food is food that you can eat without using cutlery, such as small sandwiches or nuts. It is generally served at parties and receptions where people eat standing up.

keep your fingers crossed If you keep your fingers crossed, you hope strongly that something good will happen. I put in my application for promotion and now I'm keeping my fingers crossed. Keep your fingers crossed for me when I go for the job interview.

put your finger on If you put your finger on something, you find the reason for problems or difficulties. Helena immediately put her finger on the reason for my headaches. There's something about him I don't like, though I can't quite put my finger on it.

slip through someone's fingers If something slips through someone's fingers, they miss out on a good opportunity that they had. You'll never have a chance like that againwhy did you let it slip through your fingers?
noun Your fingernails are the hard surfaces that cover the ends of the top side of your fingers.
form.note: ... SEE THE PICTUREat body.

form.definition: noun Fingerprints are marks made by the ends of the bottom side of someone's fingers. The police took the suspect's fingerprints. I don't want the kids' messy fingerprints all over the walls. You can see the potter's fingerprint in the clay.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb fingerprint The police fingerprinted the suspect.

form.definition: adjective If something is finicky, it's difficult to do because it involves very fine hand movements. Embroidery is too finicky for meI'd rather do woodwork. The model plane kit was full of finicky little pieces.

adjective If someone is finicky, they are fussy and demanding. They want every detail of something to be correct even though it's not necessary. Maryanne is so finickyshe gets upset if the blue pen's where the red one's supposed to be. Both my kids are finicky eaters.

verb When you finish a task, you bring it to an end or complete it. I'll stop when I've finished this page. He finished his education at the age of fourteen. Have you finished complaining? What time does your class finish?
verb When you finish food or drink, you consume all of it. Come on, kids, finish your dinner. Who finished that bottle of wine?

verb If something finishes you, it uses up all your energy or money. That race has finished me for the daythere's no way I can run in the relay. Paying for both my daughters' weddings within six months just about finished me.

noun The finish is the end or last part of something, especially a race or match. I want to see this project through to the finish. The Melbourne Cup saw a dramatic finish this year. There was a really close finish in the final.

noun A finish is an outer coating on a surface. The gold finish was beginning to rub off. b noun A finish is also the texture or appearance of a surface. Polish it to obtain a smooth finish. I like the matt finish on these photographs.
finish off In informal language, if you say you finish off a wounded animal or person, you mean you kill them, sometimes to put them out of pain.

finish up If you finish up somewhere or in a certain situation, you get there after going to various places or having various experiences. 'Where did you finish up last night?' 'A small wine bar in the city.' I never thought I'd finish up in Australia. Get an educationyou don't want to finish up like me.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See fiery.

form.definition: adjective If something is finite, it has a limit. The number of possibilities is very large, but finite. I'm warning you, my patience is finite.

noun Fire is the burning of some material such as wood and paper which produces red-orange flames. The clothing factory was gutted by fire. Let's light a fire so we can boil the billy. She sat staring into the fire. IN CASE OF FIRE DO NOT USE THE LIFTS
noun A fire is a device fuelled by electricity, gas, coal or kerosene and used for heating rooms. We use a gas fire in the living room during winter.
noun Fire is energy and enthusiasm that someone feels or shows about something. She spoke with real fire about the need for reform. His qualifications are impressive, but somehow he lacks fire.
verb If you fire, you shoot with a gun. Stop, or I'll fire! I fired my rifle at the rabbit. He fired six shots, but they all missed.
verb If you fire pottery, you subject it to very high temperatures so that it becomes hard. The bricks are fired in this kiln.
verb In informal language, if you say someone is fired, you mean they are dismissed from their job. Jorge was caught stealing materials and fired.
catch fire If something catches fire, it starts burning, usually by accident. Andrea's hair caught fire when she was drying it in front of a gas heater.
fire away If you tell someone to fire away, you are inviting them to start talking. OK, let's hear what you have to sayfire away!
fire brigade A fire brigade is a group of people whose job it is to fight and put out fires in buildings or the bush. I joined the local volunteer fire brigade. Dial 000 for the fire brigade.
fire drill A fire drill is an event when you practise what you must do if a fire breaks out in the building you're in. It's important to have a fire drill at least one a year.
fire engine A fire engine is a large truck loaded with equipment such as ladders and hoses to fight fires. Two fire engines were quickly at the scene of the blaze.

fire escape A fire escape is a specially insulated staircase or a set of stairs outside a building. It is a way for people to leave a building if a fire breaks out. We made our way down the fire escape. It is an offence to block a fire escape.
fire extinguisher A fire extinguisher is a device with water or a chemical substance in it that stops a fire from burning.
on fire If something is on fire, it is burning. Suddenly the whole building was on fire. He dropped the lantern and set the shed on fire.
open fire When you open fire, you start to shoot with a gun. Troops opened fire on the rebels.

set fire to If you set fire to something, you make it begin burning. A spark set fire to the carpet. She set fire to her hair by leaning across the candle. Police believe that the owner set fire to the factory deliberately.
noun Firearms are guns that a person can carry, such as revolvers or rifles.
noun A firebreak is a wide path through bush or forest where all the trees and shrubs have been cleared to prevent fire from spreading.
noun A firefighter is someone whose job it is to put out fires in buildings or the bush.
noun A fireplace is a place in a room where you can burn coal to provide warmth. They've got a wonderful old fireplace in the living room.
noun A fireplace is a structure in the open air, for example at a camp site, where you can light a fire for cooking.

adjective If something is fireproof, it is resistant to burning. It doesn't catch fire easily. We store all the contracts in a fireproof cabinet. There must be a layer of fireproof insulation between the units.
noun Firewood is any wood which is used as fuel for a fire.[qr

dictionary.entry:
fireworks`fa:I@w@:ks
noun Fireworks are objects with chemicals inside them which explode when you light them and produce coloured lights, smoke and sometimes noise. They are used for display and entertainment.
noun In informal language, you use the word fireworks to describe an outburst of anger or bad temper that you have seen someone display. Wow, you should have seen the fireworks when Sarah realised she wouldn't get the prize!

form.definition: adjective If something is firm, it is not soft and pliable, but fairly solid. It is not completely hard. What you need is a firm back support. I like to sleep on a firm mattress.
adjective If your voice or manner is firm, it gives an impression of confidence and authority. Pamela delivered her speech in a firm, clear voice. The chair greeted everyone with a firm handshake.

adjective If you are firm about something, you are not easily persuaded to change your mind once you've made a decision. Don't give in to the kids' demandsyou must be firm with them. The government took a firm stand on the new tax laws despite intense lobbying.
noun A firm is a business or company. He works for a local firm.
stand firm If you stand firm, you stand by a decision you have made. You refuse to change your mind.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb firm You need to firm those muscles up a bit.adverb firmly She dealt firmly with the culprit.noun firmness

form.definition: adjective The first thing, person or occasion is the one that comes before all others in sequence or importance. The first player to finish wins. Amy is the first girl on the left. Tom won first prize. I was very nervous the first time. The first thing to remember is not to panic.
adjective If you put something first or it comes first, it is the most important aspect of your life. Leo has always put his family firsteven when work pressures have been quite demanding.

adverb If something happens first, it happens before everything else in sequence. Which came first, the chicken or the egg? First I collected the data and then I analysed it. I'll be with you in a minutelet me finish this first. First, let me apologise.
adverb If someone does something first, they do it before everyone else. No-one has done it before them. Who arrived first? Newton first described the laws of gravity.

adverb When something first happens, it has not happened before but it does then. We first met at university and we've been friends ever since. When did you first feel this pain? When we first came to Australia, everything was strange, but I soon settled in.

at first If something is the case at first, that is how it is when you begin to experience something, but later it's different. Don't be discouraged if you don't succeed at first. At first I couldn't understand a word, but it gradually became clear.

first aid First aid is the medical help you give when someone has an accident. For example, you may clean a wound and apply a bandage, or if the accident is serious you may have to lay the person on their side or revive them. I'm doing a course in first aid. We keep a first aid kit in the bathroom cabinet.
first class If something is first class, it is of excellent quality. We must ensure that our standards are first class at all times.

first name Your first name is the name that distinguishes you from other members of your family and other people with the same surname. In Australian society most people put this before their surname. Another term for it is given name.

first things first If you say first things first, you mean that the most important thing needs to be done before everything else. No, Mario, you can't have your pocket money now. First things first: clean up your room, put the garbage out, then you can have your $5.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb firstly Firstly I don't want to, and secondly I haven't got time.

form.definition: adjective A first-class piece of work is of extremely high quality. That's a first-class job you did. Well done!
adjective If you havefirst-hand experience of something, you have been in such a situation yourself or you have done it yourself.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb first-hand I've seen it happen first-hand.

form.definition: noun A fish is an animal that lives in water. It has a scaly skin, and fins and a tail to help it swim.
noun Fish is also the meat of these animals. We had fish and chips for lunch.
verb If you fish, you try to catch fish with a rod and line or in a net. We went fishing on the Mary River last weekend. Most of the boats were already out fishing.
verb In informal language, if you say you fish for something, you mean that you reach into a container and pull it out. She fished in her handbag for her keys. He fished a $50 note from his pocket.

fishing Fishing is catching fish, as a hobby or sport, or as a commercial activity. Now I'm retired I have more time for fishing. The town's economy is dominated by fishing. There's good fishing in these waters.

dictionary.entry: fisherman`fIS@m@nfishermen noun A fisherman is someone who catches fish, either for pleasure or to make a living.

form.definition: adjective A fishy smell or taste is like the smell or taste of fish.
adjective A fishy story or situation is unreliable. You don't altogether believe or trust it. There's something fishy about the way she left early.
noun You make your hand into a fist when you close it tightly with your fingers folded into your palm. She shook her fist angrily at the protesters. I felt a fist crash into my jaw.
verb If something fits, it is the right size or shape. These jeans don't fit very well. The large size should fit Geoffrey. The lounge wouldn't fit through the door.
verb If something fits, it is suitable or appropriate. His background fits well with the job requirements. None of these courses quite fits my needs.
verb If you fit something somewhere, you find room for it. I can't fit anything more into my suitcase. Can you fit another appointment into your schedule?

verb If you fit an attachment or appliance, you install it so that it functions properly. Fit the hose to this nozzle. I'm thinking of having airconditioning fitted in my car. I called a plumber to fit the new taps.
adjective If you are fit, you are physically strong and healthy and can take exercise without becoming tired quickly. I've never felt so fit since I took up swimming each day.

adjective If something is fit for a particular purpose or situation, it is suitable or appropriate. The house isn't fit for visitorsI'll have to tidy up first. He's not fit to look after children. This is not a fit use of public funds.
noun If someone has a fit, they experience a sudden attack of uncontrolled movements of the body. He's an epileptic, but his fits are controlled by drugs.

noun The fit of something is the way it is positioned in relation to other things. The fit of the dress round the thighs isn't quite right. Trim away any surplus to get a good fit. It'll just about go in, but it's a tight fit.
fit in If you fit something in, you manage to find time for it. I try to fit in a run at least twice a week. The doctor can fit you in at 11.30.
If you fit in, you conform with other people. Somehow I felt I'd never fit in with the other students. I'm willing to fit in with whatever suits you.

fit the bill If something fits the bill, it is just what is needed for a particular purpose. That agricultural pipe fits the bill exactlyit will be perfect to drain the heavy clay section of our garden.

fits and starts If something happens in fits and starts, it begins and stops again in a jerky, uncontrolled way instead of as a steady, continuous process. The car made its way along the road in fits and starts. It's no good studying in fits and startsyou need a regular timetable.

have a fit In informal language, if you say that someone has a fit, you mean that they are very angry about something that's happened. Mum will have a fit when she realises how much money you've wasted. ... WORD FAMILYnoun See fitness.adjective See fitting.
noun Fitness is being physically strong and healthy and able to take exercise without becoming tired quickly. I decided I needed to improve my fitness.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective fitness ...a fitness club. ...a fitness regime.

form.definition: adjective In rather formal language, if you say that something is fitting, you mean that it is suitable or appropriate. On this day it is fitting that we should remember the founder of our society. The celebration was a fitting acknowledgement of all their hard work.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb fittingly

form.definition: noun Five is the number 5, four plus one. There were only five of us at the meeting last night.
adjective If you have five things, the number of things that you have adds up to five. In our family there were five children.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See fifth.

form.definition: verb If you fix something, you make it stable and firm, often by fastening it to something else. When are you going to fix that cupboard back to the wall? I'd better fix that pole with some cement or else it may come crashing down.

verb If you fix your eyes, attention or mind on something, you look at it or think about it steadily. Fix your eyes on the top line and read the letters. I fixed my attention on her hand movements. You have to fix your mind on what you want to achieve.

verb If you fix something, you decide on it or settle it. Let's fix a date for the next meeting now. We still haven't fixed who's going to do the catering. We can't fix the price until we've got a better idea of the costs.

verb If you fix something, you arrange it or deal with it. I'll get my assistant to fix accommodation for you. My cousin fixed it for us to sit in the front row. Why has this overdue account still not been fixed?
verb If you fix something that is broken, you repair it or make it work properly again. I called in a mechanic to fix the leaking washing machine.

noun In informal language, if you say you're in a fix, you mean that you are in a difficult situation. Nadja's in a real fixshe needs to visit her sister in hospital and there's no-one to look after the baby.

noun In informal language, a fix is a dose of an illegal drug such as heroin or cocaine. It is also jokingly used to talk about caffeine or nicotine. I can't start work until I've had my morning fix of coffee.

fixed If something is fixed, it is firm. It doesn't change and it is not open to negotiation. Luigi has a fixed idea that we all hate him. The loan carries a fixed interest rate. For a fixed price of $25 you can have any two courses. Are these fixed prices or can we do a deal?
fix up If you fix someone up, you help them in some way or provide for them. I need $10 for the ticket, but I've only got $5 left. Can you fix me up?
If you fix something up, you sort it out or resolve a problem. 'Oh no! Kim's just spilt her drinking chocolate on the floor.' 'Don't worry, I'll fix it up.'
noun A fixture is something that has been built permanently into a room, such as a wardrobe or cupboard.
noun If you say that someone has become a fixture somewhere, you mean that they seem to be there all the time. Norman seems to have become a permanent fixture here. Has he moved in or what?
verb If a liquid fizzes, it contains a lot of tiny bubbles of gas. I shook the can of lemonade to make it fizz more.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun fizz I like mineral water that hasn't got too much fizz in it.adjective fizzy (fizzier, fizziest) The children love brightly coloured fizzy drinks.

form.definition: A fizzer is something that begins well but fails miserably soon afterwards. Ron's beach party was a real fizzerthe rain came pouring down an hour after it started.
verb If something fizzles, it makes a hissing sound. The gas fizzled from the broken pipe.

fizzle out If something fizzles out, it is abandoned because people have lost enthusiasm or interest. Somehow our plans for a trip around the world just fizzled out, so now we're going to Bali for the holidays. Their affair fizzled out when they got to know each other better.[xp\start\[ap--flab
noun Flab is soft, fatty flesh on someone's body. You really should try to get rid of that flab on your tummy.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective flabby (flabbier, flabbiest) ...a flabby tummy. ...flabby arms.

form.definition: adjective If you are flabbergasted, you are very astonished. I was flabbergasted when Mark said he was going to work in Hong Kong.
adjective If something is flaccid, it is limp and floppy.[qr

dictionary.entry:
flagflAgflagsflaggedflagging
noun A flag is a piece of coloured cloth that is attached to a pole. It usually has a special design on it representing a particular country or organisation. The whole street was decorated with flags to welcome him home. The Aboriginal flag is black, gold and red.
verb If you flag, you lose your energy or enthusiasm. After walking 10 k I was beginning to flag. Productivity often flags in the afternoons.
flag down If you flag down a vehicle, you wave at it in order to get the driver to stop. The police were flagging down speeding cars as they came around the bend.

form.definition: noun A flagon is a large bottle in which wine or beer is sold.
adjective If you describe a bad action as flagrant, you mean that it is obvious and scandalous. This is a flagrant misuse of public funds. He has been responsible for a flagrant breach of trust.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun flagrancy adverb flagrantly She has flagrantly abused her powers.

form.definition: noun If you have a flair for something, you have a natural ability for it. Cilla's got a real flair for tennis.
noun Flair is also good taste and style. There was a certain flair in the way the house had been decorated. Renee dresses with flair.
noun In informal language, flak is criticism or blame. He announced the decision and then left me to face the flak.

noun A flake is a small, flat piece of a material. My skin is coming off in flakes. Use soap flakes to wash the really delicate articles. A few flakes of snow were starting to fall. I swept up the flakes of pastry from the floor.
verb If something flakes, it peels off in small, flat pieces. The paint is beginning to flake in the sun. Eventually the scab will flake off to reveal new skin.

flake out If you flake out, you stop being active because you are exhausted. I kept going for three weeks, but then I flaked out. In the evenings I'm too tired to do anything except flake out in front of the TV.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective flaky (flakier, flakiest) The cakes are made with flaky pastry. The paint's going all flaky in the heat.

form.definition: adjective If someone is flamboyant, they act in an extravagant way that catches people's attention. His second wife was a much more flamboyant character. I love the flamboyant costumes of the dancers. In a flamboyant gesture, he flew to Europe to put his case.

noun A flame is a pointed stream of fire. The flames leaped high into the night sky. Suddenly the wood burst into flame. Turn down the gas flame and let the soup simmer. I sterilised the needle in the flame of a candle.
If something is flaming, it is very bright or hot. Cathy has flaming red hair. These flaming January days can be difficult to take.
In informal language, flaming can be used to express anger or surprise. The new clerk's a flaming idiot. The whole thing's a flaming nuisance. Stone the flaming crowsI didn't expect to see you here!
adjective If something is flammable, it burns easily. CAUTION! FLAMMABLE GOODS
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is inflammable. This is NOT the opposite of flammable.

form.definition: noun A flan is an open pie or tart filled with a sweet or savoury filling. ...a fruit flan. ...a vegetable flan.
noun An animal's flank is the part of its body between the ribs and the hip.
noun The flank of something is one of its sides. The entire southern flank of the mountain had slipped in the earth tremor. The army was attacked on the left flank.
verb If you are flanked by people or things, they are positioned on both sides of you. The prime minister was flanked by two bodyguards. The avenue is flanked by trees.
noun Flannel is a type of soft woollen cloth. I selected a checked flannel for the suit. ... WORD FAMILYadjective flannel ...flannel trousers.
noun Flannelette is a type of soft, warm cotton cloth.
verb If something flaps, it moves loosely up and down or from side to side. The kookaburra flapped its wings and took off. The canvas kept flapping in the wind.
noun A flap is a flat part of something that is attached only along one edge. Insert flap A in slot B. Water was coming in through the tent flap.
noun Flapjacks are thick pancakes served with a sweet sauce.
verb If something flares, it suddenly burns more fiercely. The candle flared as the piece of paper floated into the flame.
noun A flare is the bright, unsteady light from a burning object. The flare from the factory fire could be seen for miles around.
noun A flare is a device that burns with a bright light and is used as a signal at sea. Our engine broke down and we had to send up distress flares.
verb If something flares, it is wider in one part than another. The skirt is fitted to the hips and then flares out to the hem. The column flares slightly in the middle.

If something such as fighting or an infection flares up, it suddenly begins or becomes more intense. Ethnic tension has flared up again recently. The virus can lie dormant for several years until something makes it flare up.
If someone flares up, they suddenly become very angry or even violent. We were discussing her work when she flared up and stormed out.
verb If something flashes, it sends out a very bright light that only lasts for an instant. Lightning flashed in the sky. I kept flashing my torch to attract attention.
verb If a thought or idea flashes into your mind, it comes to you suddenly and unexpectedly. It flashed into my mind where I'd seen her before. Strange images kept flashing into my mind.

verb If you flash something, you display it briefly. Grace flashed her engagement ring at me triumphantly. The police officer flashed his badge as he barged through the door. Monica flashed a big smile at the reporter.

verb In informal language, if you say a man flashes, you mean he commits indecent exposure. He displays his genitals in an attempt to shock people and gain sexual satisfaction. He was caught flashing in a public park.
adjective In informal language, if you say something is flash, you mean it is smart and showy, and looks expensive. I decided to go for a really flash model with all the extras.

in a flash If something happens in a flash, it happens very quickly. It all happened in a flash: one minute he was standing there and the next he'd been swept away. Don't go awayI'll be back in a flash.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun flash A flash of lightning lit up the sky. I felt a flash of recognition.noun flasher Police are looking out for a flasher who has been reported in a local park.

form.definition: noun In a movie or a novel a flashback is a scene set in an earlier time than the main action. Generally it gives some background to the action.
noun A flash flood is a sudden flood that happens without any warning. CAUTION: ROAD SUBJECT TO FLASH FLOODS
noun A flashlight is an extremely bright light used for indoor photography.
adjective If something is flashy, it is intended to impress people because it looks showy and expensive. He drives around town in a flashy sports car. She soon grew tired of the flashy way of life.

noun A flask is a glass or metal container for liquids, often in the shape of a bottle with a round body, thin neck and wide mouth. I made a flask of coffee to take to work. The mixture was bubbling away in the flask. She gave me a lovely little flask for perfume.
adjective If something is flat, it has a smooth, level surface. It is not sloping and there are no parts sticking up. The country was flat as far as the eye could see.
adjective If something is flat, it is in a horizontal position. When I had a slipped disk I was flat on my back for two weeks. Lay the paintings down flat on the floor.
adjective If something is flat, it is fully extended as a single sheet and not folded or rolled up. Open the map out flat so that we can see the whole thing.

adjective If something is flat, it is uneventful and rather boring. With so few people there, the party was rather flat. After all the excitement of the election, the next few days were rather flat. January is always a flat month for news.
adjective If something such as champagne is flat, the gas in it has escaped and it has lost its taste.
adjective A battery is flat when all the power in it has been used up.
adjective A tyre is flat when the air in it has escaped through a puncture.
noun A flat is a set of rooms for people to live in. Usually they are in large buildings which are divided into several flats. Other words for this are apartment, home unit and unit.

verb If you flat with someone, you share a rented flat with them. Usually you are all young, single people. I flat with three other students. Lara and I are going to flat together next year. I'm sick of flattingI want a place of my own.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb See flatten.

form.definition: noun A flatette is a very small flat. Usually it contains only one main room, in which you cook, eat, relax and sleep, with a small separate toilet and bathroom.
verb If you flatten something, you make it flat, smooth and level. You need to flatten the driveway a bit moreit's too bumpy.
verb In informal language, if you say you flatten someone, you mean you punch them and knock them over. Don't look at me like that, mate, or I'll flatten you!
verb If something flattens a building, it demolishes or destroys it. Cyclone Tracy flattened Darwin in 1974.

verb If you flatter somebody, you say nice things about them. Sometimes what you say is exaggerated or untrue. You may be doing this to get the person to do something you want. I was careful to flatter my boss in my report on the project.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective flattered I was flattered to be invited to the select meeting.adjective flattering It was flattering to be invited. She wore a flattering black flared skirt.noun flattery The manager is easily influenced by flattery.

form.definition: noun Flatulence is the building up of gases in the digestive system. This word is often used as a polite way of referring to burping or farting. ... WORD FAMILYadjective flatulent

verb If you flaunt something, you make sure that other people are aware of it so that they know how rich or successful you are. Kerry's flaunting his latest hi-tech toyno-one can get past his desk without having to admire it.
form.note: ... DO NOT CONFUSE this word with flout.

form.definition: noun A flautist is someone who plays the flute.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is flutist.

form.definition: noun The flavour of a food is its taste. I don't like the flavour of cheese.
noun The flavour of a place is its particular atmosphere or quality. Broome has a distinct Asian flavour while still being unmistakably and typically Australian.

flavour of the month In informal language, if you say that something is flavour of the month, you mean it is suddenly very popular or fashionable. When I won the award I was flavour of the month in the office. I'll have to ask my son which computer game is flavour of the month at the moment.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this word is flavor. ... WORD FAMILYadjective flavoured Orange flavoured drink is unlikely to contain real orange juice.noun flavouring I added a pinch of chicken flavouring.

form.definition: noun A flaw is a fault or mark in a material. The dress was reduced because of a flaw in the weave. Most diamonds have flaws that make them suitable only for industrial use.

noun A flaw in an argument or proposal is something wrong with it, for example because it is not consistent or valid. He pointed out the fundamental flaw in her position. The only flaw that I can see is the large amount we'll have to pay in advance.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective flawed His argument is deeply flawed.adjective flawless Despite her nervousness she gave a flawless performance.

form.definition: noun Flax is a plant which is grown both for its fibre, which is made into linen, and for its seeds, which are used to make oil.
noun A flea is a tiny insect that sucks blood from animals such as cats and dogs and can jump very high.
adjective If something is flea-bitten, it is old and shabby. In the middle of the room was a flea-bitten rug.
noun A flea market is a market where you can buy used goods cheaply.
verb Fled is the past tense and past participle of flee.
noun A fledgling is a very young bird that is only just learning to fly.

verb If you flee, you run away from a dangerous situation. Thousands of refugees are fleeing across the border. When they were disturbed the thieves dropped their tools and fled. My grandparents fled Nazi persecution in Europe.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See flight.

form.definition: noun A fleece is the coat of wool that covers the body of a sheep.

verb In informal language, if you say someone fleeces you, you mean they take all your belongings or money dishonestly. I can't believe it! Those burglars have completely fleeced usthey didn't even leave the curtains.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective fleecy (fleecier, fleeciest)

form.definition: noun A fleet is a large group of ships travelling together. Watching the bicentennial fleet sail into Hobart was a fantastic experience. He can trace his descent directly from a sailor who arrived in the First Fleet.
noun A fleet is a large number of vehicles belonging to the same company or organisation. Who has the maintenance contract for our car fleet?

adjective If something is fleeting, it is quick and not very intense. I only gained a fleeting impression of Singaporewe had an eight-hour stopover there. He gave the letter no more than a fleeting glance before signing it.
noun Flesh is the soft, reddish muscle tissue in animals and human beings. The cut went deep into the flesh, almost down to the bone.
noun Flesh is also the edible part of fruit.
flesh and blood Your flesh and blood are your nearest relatives. What is the world coming to if you can't even trust your own flesh and blood any more?
flesh out If you flesh something out, you provide more details. The proposal needs fleshing out with a breakdown of the costs.
in the flesh If you see or meet someone in the flesh, you see or meet them in person. I was keen to see the famous movie star in the flesh. ... WORD FAMILYadjective fleshy (fleshier, fleshiest)
verb Flew is the past tense of fly.
verb If you flex a limb or a joint, you bend it.
noun A flex is an electric cord.
flex off If you flex off from work, you leave work for the day under a flexitime scheme. I'm going to flex off now, but I'll be back tomorrow morning.

flex your muscles If you flex your muscles, you do something to make other people realise how strong or powerful you are. The trade unions are flexing their muscles againa stopwork meeting has been announced for today.
adjective If something is flexible, it can easily be bent without breaking. It is not rigid. A flexible tube is inserted through this hole.

adjective If someone is flexible, they are adaptable. They can easily adjust to a new situation. This position requires a flexible person, able to keep up with new developments and trends. Arrangements need to be flexible to cope with individual circumstances.

noun Flexitime is an arrangement where a company's employees choose what time they start work and what time they finish. They all have to be in the office during certain times of the day and work the same total number of hours.

verb If you flick something, you make a quick movement with your hand to move something in a particular way. Flick the switch over. She flicked a speck of dust off his suit. I flicked through the book to find the diagram.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun flick With a flick of his hand, Col threw the snake on the ground.

form.definition: verb If a flame flickers, it burns unsteadily.
verb If a light or image flickers, it is unsteady. It moves about slightly or varies in intensity. Our shadows flickered on the cave walls. The video's flickeringit's a very old tape.
verb If a feeling flickers, it is faint and uncertain. Perry saw hope flicker in the girl's eyes.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun flicker

form.definition: noun Flight is the movement of something through the air. The hunters shot the birds in flight. The flight of the plane became irregular before it crashed.
noun A flight is a journey by plane. Did you have a good flight? It's a 12-hour flight. Flight AN91 from Cairns to Brisbane is now boarding at Gate 10.

noun Flight is also running away from a dangerous situation. The town's population has been swollen by the flight of refugees from across the border. The gunman paused in his flight to let off a couple of shots.

noun A flight of stairs is a set of steps leading between storeys in a building. I broke my leg when I fell down a flight of stairs at the office. She lives up six flights of stairs, and that's no fun when you've got a load of shopping, a baby and a toddler.

noun A flight of fancy or imagination is an idea which is not serious or practical. The whole scheme is just another of Fabio's flights of fancy. She went off into a flight of imagination about what she would do if she won the money.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb See fly.

form.definition: adjective If something is flimsy, it is light and thin or not solidly constructed. It won't stand up well to wear or use. You can't go bushwalking in those flimsy sandals! Their flimsy hut was badly battered in the storm.
adjective A flimsy argument or excuse is not persuasive or convincing. Their case for going ahead is pretty flimsy. She made a flimsy excuse about having to help a friend.
verb If you flinch, your body makes a small, quick movement away from something because of fear or pain. Little Craig flinched when the doctor came towards him with the needle.

verb If you flinch, you allow it to be seen that you find something unpleasant or mentally painful. He flinched at the mention of his ex-wife. She bore all these tragedies without flinching, because of her faith in God.

verb If you fling something, you throw it with great force. Kim flung her bag across the room in a rage. See how far you can fling this stone. Joe came in and flung himself on the settee. She flung her arms in the air in triumph.

noun If you have a fling, you enjoy yourself without worrying about the future for a short time. Now that I've taken my final exams, I'm going to have a fling for a few weeks. Let her have her flingshe'll have to face responsibilities soon enough.

noun If you have a fling, you have a brief sexual relationship without being serious about it. Tanya's having a bit of a fling with her tennis coach. Is this another of his flings, or is he really going to leave his wife for her?
noun Flint is a very hard type of stone. You can start a fire by striking two pieces of flint together to make a spark.

verb If you flip something, you turn it over by making a movement with your hand. Let's flip a coin to see who'll do the washing up. There's a definite knack to flipping pancakes. I flipped through the pages to find what I wanted.
noun When you do a flip, you quickly stand on your hands and swing your body over to the other side. Another word for this is somersault.
flip your lid In informal language, if you say you flip your lid, you mean you become very angry. Donna completely flipped her lid when she found out the TV had broken down again.

adjective If you are flippant, you take a humorous or dismissive attitude to something that other people think is serious and important. His flippant remarks about religion were deeply distasteful to her. Do all teenagers go through this flippant phase?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun flippancy adverb flippantly[qr

dictionary.entry:
flipper`flIp@
noun A flipper is the broad flat limb of an animal such as a whale which helps it swim through the water.
noun Flippers are also long flat pieces of rubber that you attach to your feet to help you swim faster.

form.definition: verb If you flirt with someone, you put on a show of having a romantic interest in them, but you are not serious about it. Did you see Selena flirting with Damien at the party?

verb If you flirt with a plan, you think about it vaguely and wonder whether to do it, but you are not seriously making arrangements. I'm flirting with the idea of buying a bit of land and becoming a hobby farmer. ... WORD FAMILYnoun flirt Susan's a bit of a flirt, isn't she?adjective flirtatious His flirtatious manner is really irritating.
verb When something small and light flits, it moves quickly. Small birds were flitting from branch to branch.
verb When something floats, it remains on the surface of a liquid. It does not sink. Do you think this ball will float? I floated lazily on my back, looking up at the stars.

verb If something floats somewhere or if you float it there, it is carried along by a current of water or air. The leaves floated down the river. The balloon must have floated about 400 k. They float the logs down the river to a mill.
verb If a currency floats, its value in relation to other currencies is determined by market forces.

noun A float is something that is very buoyant because it contains a lot of air. It easily floats on water and can be used to support things and prevent them from sinking. When children are learning to swim they often wear floats around their upper arms.

noun A float is a trailer with a big open platform that is pulled by a lorry in a parade. On the platform things are displayed or people perform. The community groups have been working on the designs for their floats for months.
noun A float is also a trailer for transporting livestock. ...a horse float. ...a cattle float.
noun A flock is a large group of animals such as sheep or birds.
verb If people flock somewhere, they go there in large numbers. Children were flocking through the school gates. Crowds flocked to hear him speak.

dictionary.entry:
flogflOgflogsfloggedflogging 1 verb If you flog someone, you beat them severely as a punishment. The convicts were flogged mercilessly
verb In informal language, if you say you flog something, you mean that you sell it, usually cheaply. He's at the market every week, flogging bits of crockery. At the end of the trip we flogged the car for a few hundred bucks. What a way to make a living, flogging life insurance!
flog a dead horse If someone is flogging a dead horse, they refuse to give up, but keep trying to do something that has no hope of success. We've already decided we can't afford a holiday, so showing me the brochure is just flogging a dead horse.
flog to death If you flog something like a story or joke to death, you tell it so often that it becomes very boring.

form.definition: verb If a river, lake or other body of water floods, the water in it rises so high that it overflows the banks.
verb If a river or lake floods an area of land, it covers it with water. Charleville was flooded for daysthe main street was under a metre of water.
noun When land is under flood, it is covered by water although it is usually dry.

verb If something floods somewhere, a large amount of it moves in that direction. Congratulations flooded in as soon as the result was announced. People flooded out of the hall at the end of the concert. Memories came flooding back when I revisited my home town.
verb If something floods a place, a large amount of it arrives there. Every year, thousands of people flood Birdsville for the races. At the flick of a switch, bright, glaring light flooded the oval.

verb If you flood a person or a place with something, you send a large amount of it to them or to the place. Farmers are flooding the market with eggs. My letterbox gets flooded with junk mail. Mother was flooded with presents for her seventieth birthday.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun flood Floods covered the town. I got a flood of letters. I felt a flood of emotion.

form.definition: noun A floodlight is an extremely bright light used to light big outdoor areas such as sports playing fields.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb floodlight The landmarks are floodlit at night.

form.definition: noun The floor of a room is the level surface that you stand and walk on. I dropped my pen on the floor. The apartment has polished wooden floors. I placed the rug in the middle of the floor.
noun A floor in a building is all the rooms on one level. Another word for this is storey. Rita has a flat on the fourth floor. We're thinking of building on an extra floor.
noun The floor of the sea, a lake or a forest is the bottom or the ground.

verb In informal language, if you say that something floors you or that you are floored, you mean that you are completely confused. I'm not sure that Gian-Carlo understood the problemhe looked pretty floored to me.
take the floor If you take the floor, it is your turn to make a speech. When the best man took the floor, everyone settled back for a bit of entertainment.
form.note: ... SEE THE PICTURE at house.

form.definition: noun A floorboard is a length of wood in a wooden floor.
verb If something flops, it hangs or falls limply. My fringe keeps flopping into my eye. I starched the brim of my hat to stop it from flopping.
verb If you flop, you sit or lie down heavily. Tess came in and flopped down on the sofa. When you're unemployed it's easy to just flop around the house all day.
verb If something flops, it is not at all successful. The new play at the Opera House seems to have floppedthe critics loved it but the public is staying away.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See floppy.noun flop Ira's party was a complete flophardly anyone turned up.

form.definition: adjective If something is floppy, it is limp and bends easily. She was wearing a floppy hat. Look at those cute little bunnies with their floppy ears! My jacket went all floppy when I washed it.
noun A floppy disk or floppy is a small, portable magnetic disk which is used for storing computer information.
noun The flora of an area is all the plants growing there. There is a wonderful display of native Australian flora in these gardens.
adjective A floral display consists of flowers. A floral design consists of pictures of flowers. The hall was decked with floral arrangements. I chose curtains with a floral pattern.
noun A florist is a person or a shop that sells flowers. She's studying at TAFE to be a florist. There's a florist a few doors down from the bank.
noun Floss is a mass of very fine, silky threads. ...dental floss.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective flossy

form.definition: noun Flour is a powder made from edible grains. It is used to make pasta and noodles and many types of bread. ...wheat flour. ...rice flour.

verb If a plant or animal flourishes, it grows well because the conditions it lives in are favourable. That palm is really flourishing since I transplanted it into the sun. 'How are your children?' 'They're flourishing, thank you.'
verb If something flourishes, it is active and successful. Business is flourishingwe had a twenty per cent increase in orders last month. In these unclean conditions disease flourishes.

noun If you do something with a flourish, you do it with a showy or exaggerated movement. He bowed to the ladies with a flourish of his hat. Her signature is no more than a curly line and a flourish. He produced the envelope from his pocket with a flourish.
verb If someone flouts a rule, they break it openly. These corporations shouldn't get away with flouting the law.
form.note: ... DO NOT CONFUSE this word with flaunt.

form.definition: verb If a liquid flows, it moves under the influence of gravity. The river flows right past our house. The beer flowed over the sides of the glass.

verb If something else flows, it moves smoothly or steadily. Somehow the ideas just aren't flowing today. Refugees continue to flow into camps along the border. We need to get the traffic flowing again.
verb If something flows, it hangs loosely. Carlotta's hair was flowing over her shoulders. The dress flows in deep folds to the floor.
A flow chart is a diagram which shows all the steps involved in a process.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun flow We measured the rate of flow. There is a constant flow of traffic.adjective flowing She has long, flowing hair. She wore a loose, flowing dress.[qr

dictionary.entry:
flower`fla:U@
noun A flower is the decorative coloured part of a plant. Seeds develop from flowers.
b noun A flower is also a type of plant which you grow because of its attractive flowers. I planted flowers all along the borders.
verb When a plant flowers, it has flowers growing on it. Our gum tree is flowering at the moment.

form.definition: noun A flowerbed is a part of a garden where you grow plants which have attractive flowers. Our garden has a lawn surrounded by flowerbeds and a small vegetable patch at the far end.
adjective If speech or writing is flowery, it is elaborate in an unnecessary way, instead of being clear and concise. What is he actually trying to say behind all this flowery language?
verb Flown is the past participle of fly.
verb Flu is an illness that makes you suffer from a fever and usually a sore throat, a cough, a runny nose and aching limbs. I had a nasty bout of flu last week.

verb If something fluctuates, it varies a lot. It increases and decreases in an unpredictable way. Petrol prices have been fluctuating lately. The migrant intake fluctuates considerably from month to month.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun fluctuation The fluctuation is due largely to seasonal factors.

form.definition: noun A flue is a pipe attached to an indoor heater or stove through which the waste gases are taken outside.

adjective If you are fluent, you can speak, write or read without difficulty or hesitation. Karina is fluent in three languages. Peter was a fluent reader at the age of three. Sam delivered a fluent speech at the meeting. Con speaks fluent Greek and Turkish.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun fluency The fluency of his speech impressed us.adverb fluently Karina speaks three languages fluently. Sam delivered the speech fluently.

form.definition: noun Fluff is very small, light pieces of material such as cotton, wool, hair and dust. There's some fluff on your jacketlet me brush it off for you. Look at all that fluff under the bed!

verb If you fluff something, you push and shake it so as to make it less compact. Fluff the lounge cushions up a bitthey've got rather squashed. I hate your hair fluffed like thatit looks like a bird's nest.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective fluffy (fluffier, fluffiest) She held a tiny fluffy kitten. Beat the egg whites until they're fluffy.

form.definition: noun A fluid is a liquid or a gas. In everyday language, a fluid is the same as a liquid. You need to drink plenty of fluids in this hot weather. The AIDS virus has been detected in all body fluids.
adjective If something is fluid, it flows or moves smoothly. Iron becomes fluid when you heat it above 1000 degrees Celsius. When you do ballet, your movements have to be fluid.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun fluidity

form.definition: noun A fluke is something good that happens to you through sheer luck. You haven't planned for it. It was a fluke that he happened to be in town at the time. By a fluke, I was able to answer all three questions.
verb In informal language, if you say you flunk an examination or a course, you mean that you fail it.
adjective If something is fluorescent, it shines back very brightly when light falls on it. The sign was written in fluorescent paint.
A fluorescent tube is a special type of long thin light bulb that uses very little energy.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun fluorescence

form.definition: noun Fluoride is a chemical substance which strengthens teeth against decay. I bought a toothpaste with fluoride in it.

noun A flurry is a short, sudden burst of confused activity. A flurry among the waiting reporters marked the arrival of the minister. Start your preparations early so you don't have to do everything in a flurry at the last minute.
verb If you flush something, you clean it by using large amounts of water. Don't forget to flush the toilet, Tim. You'd better flush the veranda with the hosethe dog's been sick.
verb If you flush, you become red in the face because you're embarrassed, excited or hot. I still flush when people tell dirty jokes.

noun A flush is a reddening of your face or a sensation of heat going through your body. There was a flush of fever on Michaela's face. I've been having hot flushes latelycould this be the start of the menopause?
adjective If something is flush, it is flat and even. It doesn't stick out or stick up beyond the surface of something else. That cupboard door needs to be flush with the frame.

adjective If you are flush with something, you have a lot of it. We're flush with food now that we've made the weekly trip to the supermarket. We should invest in more equipment now that the business is comparatively flush with money.
verb If you fluster someone, you make them confused or embarrassed. Stop flustering me when I'm trying to concentrate on these figures! He gets terribly flustered when he has to perform in public.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun fluster She gets into a fluster.

form.definition: noun A flute is a musical instrument shaped like a pipe. You play it by blowing into a hole at one end while covering other holes in its body with your fingers. You hold it sideways beside your face.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See flautist.noun flutist

form.definition: verb If something flutters, it makes small, quick movements from side to side or up and down. Mike's shirts were fluttering in the breeze like flags. The bird fluttered its wings when I opened the cage but it didn't fly out.
verb If your heart flutters, it does not beat in a regular way. You can use this phrase to describe how you feel when you're nervous. My heart fluttered as he walked into the room.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun flutter He's got a heart flutter. I felt a flutter of excitement.

form.definition: noun A fly is a small insect with two wings. The picnic was great except for the flies!
verb When an aircraft, bird or insect flies, it moves through the air.
verb If you fly somewhere, you go there in an aircraft. Joe regularly flies to Brisbane on business.
verb If someone flies an aircraft, they control its movement through the air.
verb You can say that a loose object flies if it moves about freely in the air. Her hair was flying about in the breeze.
verb You can say that something flies in a particular direction if it moves there very quickly or with force.
noun A fly is the vertical opening down the front of a pair of trousers. He blushed when he realised his fly was undone.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See flight.

form.definition: noun A flying saucer is a round flat flying object that some people think they have seen and believe to be a space vehicle from another planet.
noun A foal is a young horse. See also filly.

noun Foam is a mass that forms on a liquid when there are many bubbles of gas in it. Look at all that foam on the surface of the riverit must be very polluted. The firefighters used foam to extinguish the blaze. ...shaving foam.
noun Foam is also a light, spongy material used as a filling in things such as cushions, pillows, mattresses and furniture.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective foam ...a foam mattress.

form.definition: fob off In informal language, if you say that someone fobs you off, you mean that they don't give you what you have asked for. Why does the Premier keep fobbing the electorate off with promises about better transport? Don't fob me off again! I want a proper explanation now.
verb When you focus a camera or focus your eyes on something, you adjust them so that the thing you are looking at is clear rather than blurred. Focus your eyes on the chart in front of you.
verb If you focus your attention on something, you concentrate on it. We need to focus our minds on more important matters right now. He was too tired to focus on the details of the conversation.

noun You can say that someone or something is the focus of attention if they receive a lot of attention. She's very witty and charmingalways the focus of attention at parties. The new building has been the focus of a lot of media interest.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGof the verb forms is focusses, focussed and focussing.

form.definition: noun Fodder is hay, straw or other food for farm animals.

noun You can also use fodder to refer to large amounts of something that is needed to keep some process going. Several tons of refuse are collected each day as fodder for the recycling plant. All these experiences were fodder for her imagination.
noun A foetus is an unborn child or animal in the later months of pregnancy. ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this is fetus. ... WORD FAMILYadjective foetal
noun Fog or a fog is a thick cloud formed by fine drops of water in the air. It is difficult to see things when there is fog. We had to drive very slowly because of the thick fog.

fog up If something such as glass fogs up, it becomes covered with a very fine layer of water. My glasses fog up every time I leave the airconditioned room and go outside. It's dangerous to drive with fogged up windows.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective foggy It was a cold, foggy morning.

form.definition: noun Foil is metal which has been hammered flat into very thin sheets. He covered the dish with kitchen foil. The cover of the book is decorated with gold foil.
verb If you foil someone's plans, you prevent them from doing what they intended to do. The presence of the police foiled the exchange of the ransom money.

verb If you fold material such as paper or fabric, you turn it over on itself so that its layers overlap and its edges touch each other. I folded the towels and put them away. Fold the letter into three and put it into the envelope. It was hard to fold up the map in the wind. Origami is the art of folding paper.

verb If you fold something such as a chair, a bed or a door, you bend it at a joint so that it turns in on itself and takes up less space. I folded the chairs and stacked them against the wall. The bed folds away during the day. The sofa folds out to form a bed.
verb If you fold your arms or legs, you cross them. You tuck them into each other. Maria folded her arms and looked crossly at Tonio. The children sat on the floor with their legs folded.
verb If a business or project folds, it fails and stops operating. The amateur theatre company folded because of lack of interest. The company folded with debts of half a million dollars.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun fold Now cut along the fold in the paper.adjective folding ...a folding chair.

form.definition: noun A folder is a flat container made of cardboard that is used for storing documents. He pulled his phone bill out of a folder on his desk.
noun Foliage refers to the leaves of plants and trees. This shrub has attractive, dark green foliage. We made our way through the dense foliage.
noun In rather old-fashioned language, folk refers to people in general. The village folk were apprehensive about the new people.

adjective Folk art, music, dance and customs are things that form part of a country's or community's traditions. We listened to a recording of German folk songs. An Irish folk dance is our next performance.
folks (a) In informal language, you can refer to your family as your folks. My folks came from Scotland.
(b) You can also use folks in an informal situation to address any group of friends or people. Come on, folks, let's show our appreciation to the cook!
noun The folklore of a country or a community is its customs and its traditional beliefs and stories.
verb If something follows something else, it comes after it. The dinner was followed by dancing. The chorus follows each of these verses. I left at that point, so I don't know what followed.
verb If you follow someone, you go along behind them. You go ahead since you know the way, and we'll follow you. He suspected that he was being followed. A long line of cars followed the hearse.
verb If you follow a road or a path, you drive or walk along it. Follow this road for about a kilometre, then turn left.

verb If you follow what someone is saying, you understand it. I was too tired to follow the lecture. I didn't understand every word in the Italian movie, but enough to follow the plot. We must see he doesn't cause troubledo you follow me?

as follows You use as follows to indicate that you are about to give detailed information, often in the form of a list. The hostel rules are as follows: no drinking, no smoking and no eating in bedrooms.

follow in someone's footsteps If you follow in someone's footsteps, you do something that they have done some time before. Andy is following in his mother's footstepshe's as mad about tennis as she is.

follow through If you follow through a long or complicated task, you keep going and finish it. You don't give up part of the way through. Tracy needs to follow the project through as she's the only person who knows all the details. He's great at having ideas, but he just doesn't follow them through.

follow up If you follow something up, you continue to be involved with it or you continue some work that has been done previously. Our heart patients are followed up after they've had their operation. We should follow the program up with more activities.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See follower.adjective See following.

form.definition: noun A follower is someone who supports or believes in something such as a cause, a political party or a religion. His followers have been active in campaigning for his release from prison. She became a follower of Islam.

adjective The following day or year is the next one, when you are talking about the past or the future. The following day I felt much better. We should break even in 1999, and make a profit the following year.

adjective You can also use following to indicate that you are about to give detailed information, often in the form of a list. Volunteers can help in any of the following ways: tidying the grounds, weeding the gardens or mowing the lawns. I'd like to thank the following people: Mary, Sam, Tony and Andrew.
preposition Following is another word for 'after'. He was in a lot of pain following the operation. Following the news we'll have the weather.
adjective Follow-up action involves the continuation of work that has been done previously. After the operation you'll need some follow-up drug treatment.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun follow-up Without effective follow-up they forget what they've learned during the course.

form.definition: noun Folly or a folly is behaviour that is foolish. It was sheer folly to attempt the climb in such poor weather. Learning to parachute is just another of her folliesit won't last long.

adjective If you are fond of someone or something, you like them or you like it very much. Of course I'm fond of my family, but I don't see them very often. It's a great restaurant if you're fond of seafood.
adjective A fond look or gesture shows affection for someone or something. He held the child in a fond embrace.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb fondly He spoke fondly of his children.noun fondness

form.definition: noun Food is what people or animals eat or drink in order to stay alive. A healthy diet should include a variety of fresh, natural food. ...a tin of cat food.
noun Food can also refer to solid food in contrast to drinks. There was plenty to drink at the party but not much food.

food for thought If you say something is food for thought, you mean that it causes you to think carefully about something. It may make you change your ideas. The lecture about time management gave me food for thought.
food processor A food processor is a machine that's used in the kitchen to chop, mince, mix or blend food.
noun Foodstuffs are any substances that people use as food.
