noun If you call someone a fool, you mean that they are stupid or silly, or have done something stupid or silly. Kay's a complete fool! How can she spend three hundred dollars on a dress when she hasn't paid the water bill? I felt such a fool when I realised I'd gone to the wrong address.

verb If someone fools you, they trick you into believing something which isn't true, usually as a joke. His disguise fooled us all. For a while she had me fooledI really believed she was going to leave.
fool around If someone fools around, they waste time being silly instead of getting on with what they ought to be doing. Stop fooling around and do your homework!

make a fool of If someone makes a fool of you, they make you seem to be silly or stupid. You can also make a fool of yourself if you do something silly or stupid. The lecturer made a fool of Howard in publicI'm not going to his lectures again. I made a complete fool of myself by putting salt in my coffee.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See folly.adjective foolish He made a foolish mistake. It would be foolish to ignore the opportunity.adverb foolishly

form.definition: adjective If something is foolproof, it isn't easy to damage it or use it the wrong way, even if you don't really know what you're doing. This little camera is completely foolproofeven a child can take good photos with it.
noun The foot is the part of the body at the end of your leg.
noun The foot of something is the bottom or end part of it. Our house is at the foot of a hill. I added my name to the foot of the list. The blankets have slipped off the foot of the bed.
noun A foot is also a unit of measurement in the imperial system. It is equal to just over 30 centimetres. He's nearly six feet tall.
If you foot the bill for something, you pay the costs involved. Who's going to foot the bill for this extravaganza? The taxpayer as usual! Col will have to foot the bill for his son's car accident.
keep your feet on the ground If you keep your feet on the ground, you are sensible and realistic. We've done very well so far, but we must keep our feet on the ground.
put your foot down If you put your foot down, you firmly use your authority in insisting on or forbidding something. I've been indulgent so far, but this time I'm putting my foot down.

stand on your own feet If you stand on your own feet, you are independent and don't rely on other people. You can emphasise this by saying stand on your own two feet. Susanna, you really have to grow up and learn to stand on your own two feet.
noun Football is a game in which two teams of players kick a ball and try to score goals. Rugby league, rugby union, soccer and Australian rules are all types of football.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this, in informal language, is footy.

form.definition: noun A football is also the ball used in any of these games.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun footballer

form.definition: Someone's footing is being able to stand upright without slipping. It was difficult to keep my footing on the wet rocks. He lost his footing and tumbled down the slope.

noun If you put something on a certain footing, you set it up so that it is that way. We need to put the project on a firm financial footing if it's to succeed. After taking the study skills course you should be on an equal footing with the other students.

noun A footnote is an addition to a piece of writing which gives extra information. It is not included in the main body of the text but appears at the bottom of the page or at the end of the chapter or book. Footnote 7 gives the source for these figures.
noun A footpath is a path, especially one that is at the side of a road or street, for pedestrians only.
noun A footprint is a mark that a foot or shoe leaves in a soft surface such as sand or mud. We could tell where the children had run by following their footprints.
noun Footsteps are the sounds that you make with your feet when you walk. We heard the gate creak and then the footsteps of someone approaching the door.
noun Footwear is what you wear on your feet, such as shoes, boots, sandals and slippers. What is the most sensible footwear for the hike?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective footwear See the incredible specials in our footwear department today.

form.definition: preposition You can use for to state the purpose of something, such as an activity or an object. Are you going for a run after tea? I'd use a thicker pen for drawing that line, if I were you.

preposition If something is for someone or something, it is meant to be used by them in some way or used in connection with them. This letter is for you. That's a nice hiding place for the money. ...a hotel for tourists.

preposition If you say something lasts for a length of time, or continues for a certain distance, that's how long it lasts or how far it travels. He's been away for days. The ball rolled for 30 metres down the hill.
preposition If you are for something, you are supporting it. I'm all for going home right now. Are you for or against the idea?
conjunction If you say you do something for a particular reason, that's why you do it. It means the same as 'because'.
form.note: ... NOTEthat for has many senses in common use. These are examples of the most frequent. ... DO NOT CONFUSEthis word with fore or four.

form.definition: verb If you forage for supplies, you go and search for them. In traditional Aboriginal society, much of the day was spent foraging for food. I foraged in the stationery cupboard for a suitable envelope.
noun In fairly formal language, forbearance is patience and tolerance when people are behaving badly. He showed great forbearance in allowing the children to roam the house and make a mess.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective forbearing

form.definition: verb If you forbid someone to do something, you don't allow them to do it. You tell them that they must not do it. The boss has forbidden us to mention the project to anyone outside the company. Smoking indoors is strictly forbidden.
adjective If someone or something is forbidding, they seem difficult to deal with. We faced a long climb up a forbidding slope. Her manner is forbidding, but she's really very kind.

verb If you force someone to do something, you make them do it, even though they don't want to. The robber forced the manager to open the safe. I can't force my son to studyhe has to find his own motivation. The new law will force companies to keep better records.
verb If you force something somewhere, you make it go there, often overcoming resistance. I forced a knife into the crack. He forced his way past the security guards.

verb If you force something such as a lock or a door, you use a lot of strength to open it, and often you break it. Hino forced the lock with a screwdriver. The window tends to stickyou have to force it a bit. If the drawer is jammed, don't force it.
noun Force is any kind of physical power or strength. The car crashed into the house with such force that the wall collapsed. The force of the explosion was felt several kilometres away.
noun If you use force to do something, you use physical strength or even violence. He had the protesters removed by force.
noun If something has force, it is effective. It was his point about costs that carried most force. The new regulations were not properly thought through and lack force.
noun In physical science, a force is an invisible influence that pushes or pulls objects. ...magnetic forces. ...the force of gravity.
noun A force is a person, group or idea that has power or influence. Ethnic groups are a political force to be reckoned with. We must use this awareness as a force for change.
noun A force is an organised body of people. ...the police force. ...the air force. More and more women with young children are joining the labour force.
noun A force is a large number of armed troops. This word is often used in the plural. They spotted an enemy force in the next valley. Our forces are better trained than theirs.
come into force When a law or regulation comes into force, it must be obeyed from that time on. These restrictions will come into force on January 1.
in force If people attend an event in force, a great number of them go to it. Parents turned up in force for the school information night.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See forceful.adjective See forcible.adjective forceful

form.definition: adjective If someone is forceful, they are energetic and assertive. You need to be a bit more forceful in claiming your due. His forceful personality saw the project to a successful conclusion.
adjective If something such as an argument or an example is described as forceful, it is effective or convincing. What happened last night is a forceful argument for stricter gun control.
form.note: ... DO NOT CONFUSEthis word with forcible. ... WORD FAMILYadverb forcefully

form.definition: noun Forceps are an instrument that is used by doctors to hold things.
form.note: ... NOTEthat this word is used in the plural form.

form.definition: adjective If something is described as forcible, it involves the use of physical strength or even violence. The broken window was a sign that the burglars had made forcible entry.
form.note: ... DO NOT CONFUSEthis word with forceful. ... WORD FAMILYadverb forcibly

form.definition: noun A ford is a shallow part of a river where people or vehicles can cross.
adjective The fore parts of something are its front parts, in contrast to the rear or hind parts. The fore limbs of the kangaroo are quite small.
to the fore If someone or something comes to the fore, they appear at the front or in the best position or they become more popular than the others.
form.note: ... DO NOT CONFUSEthis with for or four.

form.definition: noun Your forearm is the part of your arm between your elbow and your wrist.
noun Your forebears are members of your family or cultural group who lived a long time ago. This word is usually used in the plural.
noun A forecast is a statement about something that is likely to happen in the future. Did you listen to the weather forecast on the radio this morning? The economic forecast for next year is gloomy.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb forecast He forecast that interest rates would rise.

form.definition: noun Your forefinger is the finger on each hand that is next to the thumb.
form.note: ... ANOTHER TERMfor this is index finger.

form.definition: noun The foreground in a landscape, photograph or painting is the part that is nearest to you as you look at it.

noun If you say that someone or something is in the foreground, you mean that they are noticeable or receive attention. Peta is forever trying to push herself into the foregroundthe manager hardly notices the other staff any more. Economic measures are likely to be in the foreground next month.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is background.

form.definition: noun Your forehead is the part of your face above your eyes and below your hair. See the picture at body.
adjective If someone or something is foreign, they come from overseas. You shouldn't buy foreign productsbuy Australian. Foreign tourists often expect a very high standard of service.

adjective Something can be described as foreign if it is found in a place where it doesn't naturally occur. The body's immune system will often reject foreign tissue. A foreign substance was detected in the sample.
noun In formal language, if you say something is foreign to you, you mean that it seems strange and unusual. The idea was quite foreign to meI would never have thought of it myself.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun foreigner As a foreigner, Maria felt isolated at college.

form.definition: noun A foreman is the supervisor of a group of labourers or workers.
adjective If something is foremost in someone's mind, it is the most important or urgent thing. Meeting the deadline should be foremost in our minds. The foremost problem is how to maintain quality.
adjective Forensic means relating to scientific tests that are carried out in order to solve a crime. ...forensic medicine. ...a forensic laboratory.

verb If you foresee something happening, you know or assume that it is going to happen. I can foresee several difficulties with this plan. Paulo should have foreseen that he'd need to borrow more money. She claimed to have foreseen the disaster in a dream.

verb In rather formal language, if you say something foreshadows an event, you mean that it indicates that the event is likely to happen. The ground had rumbled for days, foreshadowing an eruption of the volcano. These disagreements foreshadowed more serious disputes to come.
noun A forest is a large area of land covered with trees. In Australia, this word is used for areas set aside for forestry or conservation. ...Cumberland State Forest.
noun In Australia, forest sometimes refers to large areas where trees that are not native to Australia have been planted. ...pine forest.
form.note: ... NOTELand covered with Australian native trees is generally known as bush.

form.definition: noun Forestry is the activity of planting, maintaining and harvesting trees for their timber.
adverb If something continues or lasts forever, it will never end. He swore to love her forever. This shirt is made of really tough materialyou should be able to wear it forever.

adverb If you say someone is forever doing something, you mean that they do it frequently and you find it annoying or irritating. Kerry is forever complaining about her job. My children are forever losing their bus passes.
noun A foreword is an introduction to a book which recommends it or states why it has been written. It is usually by someone other than the author of the book, often someone famous.
form.note: ... DO NOT CONFUSEthis with preface, which is an introduction by the author. The normal order is for the foreword to come before the preface.

form.definition: verb If you forfeit something, you lose your right to own it. Items on lay-by are forfeited if not paid for and collected within two months.

verb If you forge a signature or a document, you make something that looks like the real thing and try to deceive people into accepting it. Now Somphong is in real troubleshe's forged her father's signature on a cheque. They were charged with attempting to forge banknotes. 2a verb A blacksmith forges metal when he hammers and beats it into shape.
noun A forge is the special fireplace in which metal is heated before the blacksmith shapes it.

verb If you forge something such as a friendship or a relationship, you put effort into forming it because you want it to last. Australia has forged close links with a number of South-East Asian countries.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun forgery (forgeries) The painting was found to be a forgery.

form.definition: verb If you forget something, it passes out of your mind. You don't remember it. I'm sorry I forgot your birthday. I'd forgotten all about the incident. With so much else on my mind, I forgot to go to the bank. I've forgotten how to use this computer program.
verb If you forget something, you accidentally leave it behind or don't bring it with you. I forgot my umbrella on the bus. Have a good tripdon't forget your passport!
verb If you forget yourself, you let your emotions control you and do something which you would not normally do. Sally completely forgot herself and kissed Timo in the middle of the street.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective forgetful She's so forgetfulshe'll forget her own head one of these days.

form.definition: verb If you forgive someone, you don't hold a grudge against them for something wrong that they have done to you. Can you forgive me for being so tactless? He prayed for his sins to be forgiven. I'm willing to forgive, but it's not easy to forget.

verb In rather formal language you can use forgive in expressions like 'forgive me' to apologise for causing inconvenience to someone. Will you forgive me if I leave you for a moment? Forgive my stupidity, but I really haven't any idea how to use the computer.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun forgiveness adjective forgiving I have the best parents in the world they're so forgiving.

form.definition: noun A fork is an implement with prongs that you use for eating food. Martin was having difficulty with his chopsticks, so I offered him a fork.
noun A fork is also a garden tool with prongs which you use for turning over the soil.
verb A fork in a road or river is a place where it divides into two or more directions. Turn left at the next fork in the road.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb fork The path forks a little further up the hill.

form.definition: noun A forklift is a small vehicle that is used for lifting and moving heavy crates and boxes in a warehouse or factory.
adjective If you look or feel forlorn, you are lonely and sad. Vishal looked so forlorn that I wanted to do something to cheer him up.
noun A form of something is its shape, outline or appearance. A dark form appeared in the doorway. We saw the form of the skyscrapers in the distance. The cake was shaped in the form of a football.

noun The form of something is its structure or the way in which its parts are arranged into a whole. The form of your essay is good but some areas lack detail. For the exam, Anna had to learn what musical form her pieces were in. What form did the ceremony follow?
noun A form of something is also the type, kind or sort of it. What form of government is most effective for Australia? Listening to music is a great form of relaxation.

verb If you form something, you give it a particular appearance or mould it into a shape. Form the dough into a ball. These mountains were formed millions of years ago by incredible forces inside the earth.

verb If you form something, you make it come into existence or you develop it. The school council formed a committee to look into the question of a new uniform. Parents have a huge role in forming the character of their children.
verb If a number of people or parts form something, they join or link together to make it a whole. Stand up and form a circle. These vegetables will form the basis for a tasty stew.
noun A form is a document with blank spaces where you are supposed to fill in information. You'll have to complete an application form.
noun A form is also a class or all the children in one year of a school. 'What form is Carlos in?' 'Year 9, I think.'

noun Form is also the physical or emotional condition or state that someone is in. Brett was in excellent form todayhe won the race. What great form Sonya's inshe's had everyone laughing for an hour now.

true to form If you behave true to form, you behave as people expect you to or as you usually do. This phrase is mostly used in a negative way. Brown behaved true to form by abusing every journalist in the room. True to form, Celia was half an hour late.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See formation.

form.definition: adjective If something such as a dinner or a party is formal, it involves fairly strict rules of etiquette. People dress up in elegant clothes and follow social customs that they do not bother with in everyday life. The reception was much more formal than I'd expected.

adjective Something such as a garden is described as formal if it is set out in regular patterns to look neat and orderly. My grandmother had a formal garden with circular paths and a central fountain.
adjective Formal language is the type of language that is appropriate for written communication on serious topics, addressed to people you do not know well.
adjective Something is described as formal if it is done in order to comply with rules or regulations. You need to put in a formal request to the committee.
adjective Formal education is education in officially recognised schools, colleges and universities. He had little formal educationhe left school at 14but he's a shrewd businessman.

adjective A formal vote is one that is valid because it has been cast in the correct manner. ... WORD FAMILYnoun formality (formalities) The interview should be a mere formalityyou're bound to get the job.adverb formally I should like to formally welcome you to our country.

noun The format of something is what it is made up of and how its parts are arranged. They changed the format of the concert to include more solo performances. The annual report always follows a set format.

noun The formation of something is its creation or development. The formation of the colony of New South Wales was the responsibility of Captain Arthur Phillip. Dampness had led to the formation of rust on the exposed metal.
noun A formation is also a particular structure or shape that something has. The rocks have been weathered into curious formations. The planes flew past in formation.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective formative

form.definition: adjective A former friend, job, possession, and so on, is one that you had or that existed some time in the past, but not any more. They both had children from former marriages. Klaus is a former colleaguewe worked together in Port Hedland fifteen years ago. The house has been restored to its former glory.
You can use the former to refer to the first of two people or things that you mention. The opposite of this is the latter. You can either drive or walk: the former is probably more convenient.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb formerly Magda was formerly Ben's wife, but now she's married to Charles.

form.definition: adjective If something is formidable, it appears extremely difficult to do or to deal with. It is daunting. Crossing the Simpson Desert is a formidable undertaking. The new chairman faces the formidable task of saving the company from bankruptcy. She proved to be a formidable opponent.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb formidably It can get formidably hot in the desert.

form.definition: noun A formula is a group of letters, numbers or symbols expressing a relationship or fact about certain things. What's the formula for calculating the area of a circle?
noun In chemistry, a formula is a group of symbols representing the structure of atoms in a substance.
noun A formula is also a list of what is contained in something such as a medicine or a drink. The new formula contains extra vitamin C.

noun A formula is also a method of achieving something. The basic formula for good health is diet, fresh air and exercise. Mixing business and private interests is a formula for trouble. There's no magic formulait's sheer hard work.

verb If you formulate something, you put it together in a certain way after thinking about it carefully. I'm still formulating my plan to deal with the situation. I know what I want to say, but I must formulate it just right to gain her support.

verb In formal language, if you forsake someone or something, you deliberately leave them or stop having anything to do with them. He forsook his wife and children. He pledged to forsake gambling forever.
noun A fort is a group of buildings that have been strengthened to provide protection against an enemy.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is fortress.

form.definition: hold the fort If you hold the fort for someone, you look after their affairs or do their work for them while they are away for a while. Clara is holding the fort for me while I'm in hospital.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb See fortify.

form.definition: noun Your forte is something that you do or know very well. It is a particular strength of yours. Cooking isn't exactly my forte but I can make a reasonable omelette. Kim's forte is his attention to detail. I don't know much about modern paintingthe 19th century's my forte.
adverb In formal language, forth describes a movement which goes forward or away from you. Leichhardt set forth on his historic journey in 1848.
adverb In formal language, forth can also mean 'forward' or 'onwards' in time. From that moment forth, he never touched another drop of alcohol.
form.note: ... SEE ALSO back and forth at back.

form.definition: adjective If something is described as forthcoming, you expect it to happen or become available soon. Forthcoming events in the park include an open-air concert and a food festival. She was interviewed about her career and her forthcoming album.
adjective If someone is forthcoming, they are happy to talk about themselves and their interests. He has a sunny and forthcoming personality.
adjective If someone is forthright, they state their opinions openly and directly. Bella is so forthright that she's made quite a few enemies.
verb If you fortify something, you make it stronger. The regiment fortified their position and settled in for the night. Have a hot bowl of soup to fortify you against the cold.
Fortified wines are drinks such as port and sherry that are stronger in alcoholic content than ordinary wine, but not as strong as spirits.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun fortification There are traces of ancient fortifications on the hill.

form.definition: noun A fortnight is a period of two weeks.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective fortnightly He rarely missed the committee's fortnightly meetings.adverb fortnightly We get paid fortnightly.

form.definition: noun A fortress is a building or place that has been strengthened to resist attack by an enemy.
adjective If you are fortunate, good things happen to you, sometimes unexpectedly. You are lucky. He has always been a fortunate person. I was fortunate not to be seriously injured.
adjective If a situation is fortunate, things turn out well. It was fortunate that the money came through when it did. By a fortunate coincidence, we arrived at the same time.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is unfortunate. ... WORD FAMILYnoun See fortune.adverb fortunately Fortunately, no serious damage was done.

form.definition: noun Your fortune is your fate or luck. It is what happens to you in life and how things turn out. Whatever my fortune, I intend to make the most of it. We wished them good fortune on their expedition. Breaking a mirror is supposed to cause ill fortune.
noun Fortune is also prosperity. It is material success and wealth. May all your family be blessed with fortune.
noun A fortune is a great deal of money. Steve inherited a fortune when his uncle died. Their renovations must have cost a fortune.
tell someone's fortune If a person with special insight tells someone's fortune, they tell them what is going to happen to them in the future and what sort of life they will have.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See fortunate.

form.definition: noun Forty is the number 40, four lots of ten.
adjective If you have forty things, the number of things you have adds up to forty.
forties The forties in the twentieth century are from 1940 to 1949, in the nineteenth century from 1840 to 1849, and so on.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective fortieth Is Karl having a fortieth birthday party?

form.definition: noun A forum is something that provides an opportunity for people to discuss things publicly, such as a meeting or the letters published in a newspaper. He's a regular contributor to the travel forum on the college computer network.
adverb If you move forward, you go from where you are in the direction that you are facing. The car jerked forward and then came to a halt on the grass.
adverb If things move forward, they make progress. The project was in question for a while, but it's moving forward again now. I feel I'm really going forward with my studies this year.
adverb If you look forward, you turn your mind towards the future. We need to look forward and forget about past mistakes and problems.
adverb If you move an event forward, you move it to an earlier time than was originally planned. Can we move the pottery class forward by an hour? The launch has been brought forward to next month.
adjective Forward planning involves thinking ahead and organising things for the future.

adjective If someone is forward, they are open, direct and bold in dealing with other people. Being forward can sometimes scare other people off. I nearly volunteered, but I didn't want to appear too forward. You need to be pretty forward if you want to get noticed.

verb If you forward something, you send it on somewhere, often to a person's new address. Would you mind forwarding my mail to me while I'm away? I signed the invoice and forwarded it to the accounts department. We will forward the item on receipt of your payment.
backwards and forwards If something moves backwards and forwards, it keeps moving in one direction and then in the opposite direction. He travels backwards and forwards between Tokyo and Sydney.

look forward to If you look forward to something, you eagerly wait for it to happen. You expect that you will enjoy it very much. I'm really looking forward to the Christmas break. I look forward to meeting you again.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective forwarding ...a forwarding address.

form.definition: verb If you fossick, you look for minerals or fossils in the ground. Alberto went fossicking for gold near Kalgoorlie in the holidays.
verb If you fossick for something, you have a look around to see if you can find it. Sandra loves to go fossicking for antiques at garage sales.
noun A fossil is the remains of a plant or animal from many thousands of years ago, preserved as a pattern in rock.
verb If you foster children, you look after them, sometimes in return for pay, although you are not their natural or legal parent.

verb If you foster something such as a plan or an idea, you support and encourage it. You help it to develop. Our community needs to foster the talents of young people. These meetings help to foster good relations within the team. The uncertainty fostered an atmosphere of tension.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective foster ...a foster parent. ...a foster child.

form.definition: verb Fought is the past tense and past participle of fight.

adjective If something is foul, it is extremely unpleasant. There was a foul smell of rotting fish. The weather has been foul all week. I've had a foul day at work. The soup tasted foulit had far too much garlic in it.
adjective Foul language consists of swear words and obscenities.
verb If an animal fouls a place, it leaves faeces there. You can be fined for allowing your dog to foul the pavement.
foul play If there is foul play in a situation, something unlawful or criminal has occurred. Police think the old man died of natural causes and foul play was not involved.

foul up In informal language, if you say you foul up or foul something up, you mean that you make a mistake and spoil what you are trying to do. Bernie's fouled up againhe's totally incompetent. It seemed that someone had fouled up the arrangements.
adjective If someone is foul-mouthed, they use a lot of offensive and obscene language. What a foul-mouthed lout Kyle has turned intoI was shocked when I heard him at the football match.
verb Found is the past tense and past participle of find.
verb If you found something such as a business or a club, you start it. You set it up. Our family business was founded in 1841. A group of dissatisfied members decided to found a rival organisation.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See foundation.noun founder Who was the founder of the club?

form.definition: noun The foundation of something is founding it or setting it up. The business has occupied the same premises since its foundation.

noun The foundation of a building is the part which is at the bottom and supports the rest of the structure. It is often below the level of the ground. This word is often used in the plural. I didn't buy the housethe foundations had shifted badly and there were cracks in the walls. b noun The foundation is also the base on which any structure or organisation stands. The dessert has a foundation of meringue, topped with layers of fruit and cream. We need experienced staff to provide a firm foundation for the team.
noun A foundation is a charitable organisation which collects and distributes money in support of a particular activity. He left his money to one of the cancer foundations.
noun A fountain is an ornamental structure, usually in the open air, which uses pipes and pumps to shoot water through the air into a pool. We arranged to meet by the Archibald Fountain in Hyde Park.
noun A fountain pen is a pen that you have to refill regularly with ink from a bottle or with cartridges.
noun Four is the number 4, three plus one. There are four in our familyMum and Dad, Bill and me.
adjective If you have four things, the number of things you have adds up to four.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See fourth.

form.definition: noun Afour-letter word is a rude or obscene word. In English many of these words contain four letters.
noun Fourteen is the number 14, ten plus four.
adjective If you have fourteen things, the number of things you have adds up to fourteen.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See fourteenth.

form.definition: noun The fourteenth person or thing is the one that comes in order after the thirteenth.
noun A fourteenth is also one of fourteen equal parts.
adjective The fourth person or thing is the one that comes in order after the third. Vyt was the fourth person to ask that question.
noun A fourth is also one of four equal parts. A more usual word for this is quarter. Each of the children inherited a fourth of their parents' wealth.

noun A four-wheel drive is a car in which each of the four wheels is directly connected to the source of power, rather than only two. Because of this, it can travel over extremely rough or soft ground.
noun A fox is an animal which has red fur and is related to the dog. It originally came from Europe, but is now found in Australia. It is a threat to native animals.
noun The foyer of a public building is its entrance hall. Let's meet in the hotel foyer at noon.
noun In mathematics, a fraction is a number that comes between two whole numbers, such as 3/4 or 4 1/2.

noun A fraction is also a small part of something. I bought this computer for a fraction of the original price. I wish I had a fraction of Jenny's energy! Could you open the window another fraction, please?
verb If an object fractures, it cracks or breaks. He fell and fractured his arm.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun fracture My grandmother's in hospital with a hip fracture.

form.definition: adjective If something is fragile, it can be easily broken or damaged. FRAGILE: GLASS These ornaments are beautiful, but they're too fragile to get home safely. Her health has been fragile lately. The experience shattered his fragile confidence.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun fragility

form.definition: noun A fragment is a small part of something, often of something that has been broken. Archaeologists have managed to reconstruct this old Khmer vase from fragments.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective fragmentary

form.definition: noun A fragrance is a pleasant smell. I breathed in the fragrance of the blossoms. The soap comes in several fragrances: rose, sea breeze and tropical cocktail.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective fragrant ...fragrant flowers.

form.definition: adjective If someone is frail, they are physically weak because they are sick or very old. My grandmother has become very frail since her accident, but mentally she's as alert as ever.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun frailty

form.definition: noun A frame is a structure that surrounds something in order to hold it in place or make it look more attractive. ...a window frame. ...a picture frame.
noun A frame is also a firm structure made from a number of parts which supports something. The house is basically a steel frame filled in with concrete panels.
verb If you frame something, you put it in a frame in order to display it. She was so delighted with the drawing that she had it framed.
verb If someone frames you, they make it appear that you are guilty of a crime even though you are really innocent. The accused maintained that he had been framed by the police.

Your frame of mind is your mental state. It is how you feel at a particular time. You can imagine her frame of mind after losing both parents in that awful accident. Get some sleep nowyou'll feel in a better frame of mind in the morning.

noun A framework is a structured plan, idea or situation. The report gives us a useful framework for proceeding. We must look at his decision within the framework of the period. Children need a solid framework in which to test boundaries.
noun A framework is also a structure that supports something such as a building, plane or ship.
noun A franchise is a business that trades under the name of a large group, but is operated as an independent business. Radek used his redundancy pay to buy a fast food franchise.
adjective If you are frank, you are honest and outspoken. I wish he had been frank with me from the beginning. To be frank, you have very little chance of promotion.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb frankly Tell me frankly if you hate it. Frankly, it's a complete waste of time.noun frankness.

form.definition: noun A frankfurt is a long, thin sausage that is red on the outside. You cook it by heating it in water.

adjective If you are frantic, you are unable to keep calm because you are feeling great anxiety, excitement or some other strong emotion. Beth still wasn't home and her parents were frantic with worry. The waiting fans became frantic as their idols appeared on stage.
adjective If a situation is frantic, it keeps you extremely busy and under great stress. With three people away, it's been frantic in the office all week.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb frantically He paced frantically up and down.

form.definition: adjective Fraternal means relating to a brother. ...fraternal love.
adjective Fraternal also means friendly, or having friendly ties with another group. The party's head office sent fraternal messages of support to its regional branches.

noun If you commit fraud, you try to gain something by deceiving people in some way, such as by forging documents. The solicitor was convicted of fraud after cheating clients out of money from trust funds over a period of ten years.
noun A fraud is also a person who is not really what they claim to be. It turned out that he was a fraud who had posed as a doctor before. You fraud! I thought your leg was supposed to be sore!
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective fraudulent He was accused of fraudulent behaviour.

form.definition: adjective If a situation is fraught with something such as danger or tension, it is full of it. The experiment is fraught with risks. The atmosphere was fraught with barely suppressed resentment.

verb If something such as a cloth or a rope frays, some of its fibres wear through and it begins to come apart. The collar of this shirt is beginning to fray. The window cords were dangerously frayed.
verb If your temper frays, you become irritated and on the point of losing your temper. The hot weather made everyone's tempers fray.
noun You can refer to a loud and wild uproar or fight as the fray. Whenever there's a brawl, Ken's always in the midst of the fray.
adjective If you are frazzled, you feel tired and irritable because you are under a lot of stress. I was completely frazzled after a day's shopping in the city.

noun A freak is someone or something that is very unusual. The storm last night was a freakit hasn't rained so much in one day for ten years. That guy's a complete freakhe won't talk to anyone and he wears weird clothes.
freak out (a) If someone freaks out, they behave in a very extreme and unusual way as though they have become insane. This word is often used to describe behaviour under the influence of drugs.

(b) In informal language, if you say someone freaks out, you mean that they become very angry or excited. I hope Murray doesn't freak out when I tell him I've lost his book. Darla freaked out when she discovered she'd won the lottery.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective freak The state has been plunged into chaos by freak weather conditions.adjective freakish That haircut makes him look pretty freakish.

form.definition: noun Freckles are small, pale brown spots that some people, especially people with fair or red hair, have on their face or arms.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective freckled

form.definition: adjective If something is free, you do not have to pay for it. Call for our free brochure. ADMISSION FREE Buy two, get one free.
adjective If a person or animal is free, they can move about without being stopped or restrained. How does it feel to be a free man after so many years in jail?
adjective If someone is free at a particular time, they are not busy doing anything. Are you free on Saturday night? Would you like to come to dinner? Could I have a word with you when you're free?
adjective If something that is available to be used by people is free, it isn't being used by anyone at the moment. Excuse me, is this seat free?
adjective If someone tells you that you are free to do something, they mean that you may do it. You are free to add any comments you wish.
verb If you free a person or thing that has been confined or restrained, you release them. She freed the bird from its cage. They argued that they should be freed from petty restrictions.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See freedom.adverb freely She spoke freely about her problems. Should pornography be freely available?adverb free Once the birds have recovered they will be set free.

form.definition: noun In informal language, a freebie is something that you get without paying for it. They were promoting the new soft drink by handing out freebies at the street fair. The whole trip was a freebie paid for by the holiday company.
noun Freedom is the state of being able to move about without being stopped or restrained by another person. The prisoners of war were granted their freedom at last.
noun Freedom is also being able to act or speak as you wish to. Young people today have so much more freedom than we used to.
noun A free-for-all is a situation that is out of control and everyone seeks their own advantage. Without regulation the industry will become a dangerous free-for-all.
adverb If you draw something freehand, you draw it by hand, without the help of anything such as a ruler or a pair of compasses. She can draw a perfect circle freehand.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective freehand ...a freehand sketch of the layout.

form.definition: noun Freehold is a type of real estate ownership where the person holds the property for an unlimited time and there are no conditions attached. The opposite of this is leasehold. ... WORD FAMILYadjective freehold ...a freehold property.
adverb If you work freelance, you are self-employed and do jobs for various organisations in return for a fee. This word is usually used about people such as journalists, photographers and designers.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective ...a freelance reporter. ...a freelance editor.noun freelance (<or> freelancer)

form.definition: noun A freeloader is someone who tries to get things such as food and accommodation without paying for it. Her brother's been staying with them for monthshe's a real freeloader.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb freeload

form.definition: adjective Free-range eggs come from hens that are not kept in cages or batteries for the whole of their lives. They are let free for a considerable part of each day.
noun Freestyle is a style of swimming in which the head and the front of the body are kept flat in the water, while the legs kick and the arms are used in turn to come up and over the head.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is the crawl.

form.definition: noun A freeway is a road specially designed for fast-moving traffic. There are usually three lanes in each direction. You must not stop on a freeway.

verb If something freezes, it becomes solid because its temperature is less than a certain . The opposite of this is melt. The water in the dam had frozen overnight. I decided to freeze the rest of the soup for later.
verb If you say something is freezing, you mean that it is very cold. I'm freezingcan't we close the window? It's freezing in here.
verb If someone freezes, they suddenly stop moving and keep very still. At the sound of her father approaching, Hannah froze.

verb If a company or authority freezes something such as prices or wages, they make them stay at the same level. They do not allow them to rise. We have decided to freeze our prices for a second year. ... WORD FAMILYnoun freeze ...a price freeze. ...a wage freeze.

verb Things such as food and blood products are freeze-dried by removing most of the water from them while they are frozen. The result of this is that they will keep for a long time without deteriorating.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun freeze-drying

form.definition: noun A freezer is an electric appliance or part of a refrigerator in which you can keep food below freezing point for a long time.
noun Freight is goods that are transported from one place to another by land, sea or air. There's a lot of freight waiting to go over to Perth.
noun Freight is also the transporting of goods. There will be a charge of $25 for freight and insurance. They sent over five hundred copies of the book by air freight.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb freight I packed up my furniture and had it freighted out to me.adjective freight She runs a freight company.

form.definition: adjective If someone or something comes from France, you describe them as French.
noun French is the language of France. It is also an official language in Belgium, Switzerland and Canada.
adjective If something is frenetic, it involves a lot of excitement, bustle and stress. The campaign headquarters was the scene of frenetic activity. We were all working at a frenetic pace.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb frenetically

form.definition: noun If you are in a frenzy, you are in a very excited and almost uncontrolled state of mind. The more he thought about it the angrier he became, until he had worked himself up into a complete frenzy. She ran out of the house in a frenzy of grief.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective frenzied He made a frenzied effort to tidy up.

form.definition: noun The frequency of something is how often it happens. Accidents occur on this corner with alarming frequency. They've increased the frequency of buses to the city in peak hours.

noun The frequency of a radio or other wave is the number of cycles of vibration that occur in a given unit of time, usually a second. Radio stations operating on low frequencies are more affected by other electrical signals than those on high frequencies.

adjective If an event is frequent, it happens often. My daughter's illness has meant frequent visits to the hospital. Clare soon became a frequent visitor to our house. This shampoo is suitable for frequent use.
adjective In rather formal language, if you say you frequent a place, you mean that you go there quite often. He was a familiar figure to all who frequented the restaurant.
form.note: ... NOTEthat there is a different pronunciation for the adjective and the verb. ... WORD FAMILYadverb frequently How frequently do the buses run? I've frequently had reason to complain.

form.definition: adjective Food is said to be fresh if it is in its natural state and not treated in any way to preserve it. I eat lots of fresh fruit and vegetablesnothing tinned or frozen.
adjective Something is also fresh if it's cool, clean and pure. I need a breath of fresh air. We drank the fresh water from the spring.
adjective Something is also fresh if it's new and different from what there was before. Why don't you two have a good talk and try to make a fresh start? We need to take a fresh look at the problem.
adjective If you feel fresh, you feel healthy and lively. You are not tired or bored. You'll feel much fresher after a good night's sleep.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun freshness

form.definition: adjective A freshwater environment, such as a river or lake, doesn't have salt in it like the sea. Freshwater crocodiles are less dangerous than saltwater ones.

verb If you fret, you keep thinking or worrying about something that makes you anxious or sad. Gloria fretted for weeks over the loss of her dog. Don't fretI'm sure they'll get back safely. There's no point in fretting about the past.

noun Friction is the force of resistance between two surfaces that rub or move against each other. If it were not for friction, the object would keep moving for ever. The joints are lubricated to reduce friction.

noun If there is friction between people, they do not get on well together. They irritate each other and often disagree about minor matters. There's been a lot of friction among the staff over the new working arrangements.
noun Friday is the sixth day of the week and follows Thursday.
noun Fridge is a shortened, informal word for refrigerator.
verb Fried is the past tense and past participle of fry.
noun A friend is someone you know well and like. Greta's one of my closest friends. Harry and Janos have been friends for years.
make friends If you make friends with someone, you become each other's friend.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See friendly.noun See friendship.

form.definition: adjective If you are friendly to someone, you are kind and pleasant to them. Our fellow travellers were very friendly and we had a great time. Are you still on friendly terms with him after the argument? ...a friendly smile. ...a friendly invitation.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun friendliness

form.definition: noun A friendship is a relationship between two people who are friends with each other. Friendship is the state of being friends with someone. Their friendship began while they were students. We really value your friendship and support.
noun Fright is sudden, strong fear. He gave me a fright when he started yelling at me. I was filled with fright when I saw the shadow in the doorway.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb See frighten.

form.definition: verb If something frightens you, it makes you suddenly feel afraid or anxious. The big dog frightened the little boy. It frightens me to think he might have an accident.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective frightened She had a frightened expression on her face. Are you frightened of spiders?

form.definition: adjective If you say that something is frightful, you mean that it is terrible, shocking or unpleasant. It was a frightful accident. His room is always a frightful mess.

adjective In informal language, you can use frightful to emphasise how bad something is. Poor Mary's caught a frightful cold. Jack's been a frightful pain in the arse lately. What's that frightful smell!
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb frightfully We were frightfully late. Oh, I'm frightfully sorry.

form.definition: adjective A frill is a strip of material that is attached to something such as a dress or tablecloth as a decoration.

frills Frills are extra things that are not really needed. Our hotel has all the frills you could wish for: tennis court, pool, room service, and more. The food here is very basic and simple with no frills.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb frilly She was wearing frilly underwear.

form.definition: noun The fringe of something is its edge, border or margin. We reached the fringe of the town. The garden has a fringe of trees around it.
noun A fringe is a border of loosely linked threads on something such as a tablecloth, shawl, rug or blanket.
noun A fringe is hair that is cut so that the edges form a straight line across your forehead.
fringe group A fringe group is a group of people with a way of life that is very different from, and often not acceptable to, the main part of society.
fringe benefits Fringe benefits are things that you get with a job in addition to your salary, such as a car, airfares or free accommodation.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective fringe ...fringe dwellers. ...fringe camps.

form.definition: verb If someone frisks you, they search your body with their hands in order to see if you are hiding something such as a weapon in your clothes. The police frisked the suspect and found a few grams of heroin.
noun A fritter is a slice of fruit that has been covered in batter and fried. Can I have six pineapple fritters, please? ...apple fritters.
fritter away If you fritter away time or money, you waste it little by little. I was going to write letters today, but I frittered away my time reading magazines.
adjective Something that is frivolous is not serious or important. You have to make an important decision so stop being frivolous. ...a frivolous remark. ...a frivolous person.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun frivolity

form.definition: adjective Frizzy hair has a lot of small, stiff curls. Is your hair naturally frizzy?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb frizz Helen's had her hair frizzed.

form.definition: noun A frock is a woman's or girl's dress.
noun A frog is a small animal that lives in water or on land. It has smooth skin and long back legs that it uses for jumping. It has no tail.
frog in your throat If you have a frog in your throat, you have difficulty speaking and your voice sounds hoarse, usually because you have a cold.
noun A frogman is someone who works underwater, wearing special breathing equipment and rubber clothing.
verb When children frolic, they move around and play in a happy, lively way. We watched the children frolicking around in the water.

preposition From is used to indicate a starting point of some kind. You use it to say that something is distant from something else, either in time or place, or in some other way. You can also use it to refer to an origin or a cause. We're walking from here to the beach. ...from now until next week. I'll get it from the office. I don't know where he got the idea from.
noun The front of something is the part that faces something else or that you normally look at. We walked to the front of the building. Our house is on the river front. ...a shop front.
noun A battle front is the part of an army which is closest to the enemy.
noun If something acts as a front for an activity, it is a cover for something that is probably illegal or secret.
noun A front is also a group of people, or a movement, which wants to achieve a political aim.
in front of Anything that is in front of an object is placed before it, especially if it is between you and the object as you look at it.
front up If you front up, you arrive or turn up somewhere.
up front If you pay for something up front, you pay for it in advance, before you receive it. If the car costs $30 000, I'll pay $5000 up front and the rest when it's delivered.
noun A frontier is a border between two countries.
noun When there is frost, the temperature falls below freezing point and a thin layer of ice forms on the ground. The late frosts this winter killed many young plants.
noun Frost is also the thin layer of ice that's formed on the ground when the temperature falls below freezing point. It's so cold the car's covered with frost in the morning.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective frosty It was a cold, frosty morning.

form.definition: noun Frostbite is damage to your body, especially your fingers, toes or ears, that's caused by extreme cold.
noun Froth is a mass of small bubbles on the surface of a liquid.
form.note: ... A SIMILAR WORDfor this is foam. ... WORD FAMILYadjective frothy

form.definition: verb If you frown, you wrinkle the skin on your forehead by moving your eyebrows closer together, usually because you are angry, worried, or thinking hard. He frowned in disbelief when he heard the strange news.
frown on or upon If you frown on or upon something, you do not approve of it. Using bad language is frowned upon in our family. They frowned on her suggestion.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun frown

form.definition: verb Froze is the past tense of freeze.
verb Frozen is the past participle of freeze.
adjective If you are frugal, you are careful not to spend too much or waste money. She has a frugal way of life despite having a good salary.
adjective A frugal meal is simple and cheap. He eats a frugal breakfast of toast and tea.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb frugally

form.definition: noun A fruit is a part of a plant that contains seeds or a stone and that you can eat. Examples of fruit are apples and oranges.

noun The fruit of something you do is its results, especially good ones. After years of hard work he's enjoying the fruits of his labour. ... WORD FAMILYadjective fruitful ...a fruitful project.adjective fruity This wine has a rich, fruity flavour.
noun A fruitcake is a cake that contains a lot of dried fruit.
verb If something frustrates you, it prevents you from doing something and makes you feel annoyed or angry.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun frustration

form.definition: verb If you fry something, you cook it in hot fat or oil. Fry the onions first, then the meat.
verb In informal language, to fuck means to have sexual intercourse.
form.note: ... NOTEthat this word is felt by many people to be offensive! With its adjective form, fucking, it is used by many people to express anger or frustration. ... WORD FAMILYnoun fuck

form.definition: noun In informal language, a fuckwit is an idiot.
form.note: ... NOTE that this word is felt by many people to be offensive!

form.definition: noun Fudge is a soft sweet made from sugar, milk and butter.
noun Fuel is a material such as oil, wood or petrol that can be burned to produce heat and energy. Save fuel! Leave your car at home and walk.
verb If you fuel something, you provide it with energy. This heater is fuelled by gas.
verb If you fuel something such as an argument, gossip or a rumour, you make it worse. You make it spread and grow. By getting a job Karen's fuelled the rumour that her husband's bankrupt.
noun A fugitive is a person who is running away from someone such as the police or from a bad situation. The two fugitives were caught a week after they had escaped from gaol.
verb If you fulfil something such as a promise, you do what you promised to do. At this rate we'll never fulfil our dream of travelling to Europe.

verb If something you are doing fulfils you, it makes you feel satisfied or happy. Teaching really fulfils me; I love to see children learn and grow. ... WORD FAMILYadjective fulfilling ...a fulfilling job. ...a fulfilling relationship.noun fulfilment
adjective If something is full, it contains as many things or as much of a substance as can fit into it. The garbage bins were full of empty cans. I couldn't add any milkthe cup was already full.
adjective You can say that something is full of things or people if it contains a large number of them. Ron's teeth are full of fillings. The supermarket was full of shoppers.

adjective You can say something or someone is full of a particular feeling or feature if they have a lot of it. Mary's trip had been full of excitement. The streets are full of danger for young people. His face was full of sorrow.

adjective Full can also indicate the greatest amount or degree that something can reach. The cars were racing at full speed. He gave the matter his full attention. The patient has made a full recovery.
adjective A full name, address, number, and so on, is the whole of it. It is complete. Please write your full name and address on the form. Are you sure he's told you the full story?
adjective In informal language, if you say that someone is full, you mean that they've had enough or too much to eat or drink. Don't give me any more to eat; I'm full. He's too full to drive home.
adverb You can use full to indicate that a person or things looks at or hits something directly. He was too embarrassed to look me full in the face. The ball hit him full on the nose.
noun A full stop is the punctuation mark (.) which is used at the end of a sentence.

dictionary.entry:
full-timefUl-`ta:Im; <or, before the noun,>`fUl-ta:Im
adjective Work or study that's full-time takes up all the hours of a normal working week rather than only part of it. Now I've got a full-time job. ...a full-time course.
... COMPARE THISwith part-time. The word is often spelt without the hyphen: fulltime. ... WORD FAMILYadverb full-time ...working full-time.

form.definition: adjective If something is described as fully-fledged, it has completed its development into that thing. After all those years of study, Kieran is a fully-fledged doctor now. The situation has gone from being an embarrassing incident to a fully-fledged crisis for the government.

verb If you fumble with an object, you feel it with your hands in a clumsy way. If you fumble in a container, you search for something in it with your hands in a clumsy way. Stop fumbling with those scissors and get on with the job. She fumbled in her handbag for the keys.
noun Fumes are gases or smoke with a strong, unpleasant smell. The room was full of tobacco fumes. Can you smell the fumes from the exhaust?
verb If you fume, you show that you are angry or annoyed. He was fuming because they had kept him waiting so long.
verb If you fumigate a room or building, you use the fumes of special chemicals to kill the germs or insects in it.
noun If you have fun, you enjoy yourself. The children had a lot of fun at the zoo. 'We're going to the footy tonight.' 'Have fun!'
noun If an activity is fun, it is enjoyable, amusing or pleasant. Bushwalking with a group of friends is great fun. It's no fun being in hospital.

make fun of If you make fun of a person or thing, you cause people to laugh at them, usually by saying unkind things about them. Ross often makes fun of his brother for not being interested in sport. My son has complained that the other children at school make fun of him.

noun The function of something or someone is the purpose or useful task that they do or are supposed to do. This machine has two functions: chopping and mixing. The personnel manager's main function is to recruit new staff.

verb If something such as a machine functions, it works or operates. The clock has stopped functioning. My brain doesn't function properly when I'm tired. You'll quickly get used to the way the office functions.

verb If something or someone functions as a particular thing, they perform the function or do the work of that thing. On the bus to work his briefcase functions as a desk. Have we got someone who could function as an interpreter?
noun A function is a formal or official party. The hotel has a large room for functions such as wedding receptions and conferences.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See functional.

form.definition: adjective If an object is functional, it is made to be useful rather than decorative. These chairs are functional but I'd like something more stylish.
adjective If something is functional, it is working or operating. We got rid of the old fridge even though it was still functional.

noun Funds are amounts of money that a person or organisation has available for spending. The road construction project is soaking up government funds very rapidly. We don't have enough funds to buy a new TV.

noun A fund is an amount of money saved for a particular purpose. A special relief fund has been set up to assist victims of the bushfires. Are you a member of a private health fund? ...a superannuation fund.
verb If you fund something, you provide money for it. The local council will no longer fund the youth crisis centre.
noun If you have a fund of something, you have a lot of it. Brian has a fund of knowledge about oriental furniture.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun funding The women's refuge has applied for increased funding.

form.definition: adjective If something is described as fundamental, it is very important, essential or basic. Our fundamental responsibility is to make sure the children are safe and happy. He lacks even the most fundamental social skills.
noun The fundamentals of an activity or system are its most important aspects. Reading, writing and arithmetic are the fundamentals of education.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb fundamentally Our ideas are fundamentally different.

form.definition: noun A funeral is a ceremony in which a dead person is buried or cremated.
noun Fungus or a fungus is a plant that has no leaves or green parts. A common type of fungus is mould.
noun A funnel is an object that is used for pouring liquids or powders into containers that have narrow openings. It has a wide, round top and a short tube at the bottom.
noun A funnel is also a metal chimney, especially on a ship or steam train.
verb If you funnel something somewhere, you make it move through a narrow space. We funnelled the petrol into a plastic container and carried it to the car.
verb If you funnel goods, information or money somewhere, you send it there from various places. Smart investors are funnelling their money into international shares.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See funnel-web.

form.definition: noun A funnel-web is a large, black and very poisonous spider that lives in eastern Australia. It builds funnel-shaped nests in the ground.
adjective You can say that something is funny if it makes you laugh or smile. Geoff told us an extremely funny joke. Everyone was laughing when I came in so I asked what was so funny.

adjective You can say something is funny if it is strange or difficult to understand or explain. The fridge is making a funny noise. It's funny that she didn't mention her husband's illness. I had the funny feeling we were on the wrong bus.
noun Fur is the thick hair that covers the bodies of many animals. Our cat has long, soft fur.
noun A fur is a piece of clothing made from real or synthetic fur.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective furry Children love stroking cats and other furry animals.

form.definition: adjective If you are furious, you are extremely angry. Kevin was furious when his wife admitted she had lost the money.
adjective You can say something is furious if it happens in a violent or very fast way. A furious storm swept through the forest damaging many trees.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See fury.adverb furiously He was furiously searching for his keys.

form.definition: noun A furnace is a large oven producing a lot of heat that's used for melting metal, heating buildings, burning rubbish, and so on.
verb If you furnish a room, you put things such as furniture, lamps and curtains in it. It took us a year to furnish our flat properly.

verb To furnish someone with something means to provide or supply them with it. Who will furnish the team members with travelling expenses? The police have just furnished an important piece of evidence against the accused.
furnishing The furnishings of a room are things such as the furniture, electrical equipment and decorations in it. The furnishings in their house are cheap but practical and in good taste.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective furnished We'd like to rent a furnished unit.

form.definition: noun Furniture is movable objects such as chairs, tables and beds that make a room suitable for living or working in. We rearranged the furniture to make room for the new bookshelf.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb See furnish.

form.definition: noun A furore is a group of people's angry reaction to something. The announcement of the spending cuts has created a furore.
noun A furrow is a long, narrow channel that is dug in the soil, usually to plant seeds in it.
noun A furrow is also a deep line or wrinkle in the skin of a person's face.
adjective Further is the comparative form of far. It is often used instead of farther when referring to distance. Don't look any further. Dim Jim has the cheapest videos in town!
adjective A further thing is an additional one. For further information, ring us on the number below. Further research is necessary.
verb If you further something, you help it develop.
adjective Furthest is the superlative form of far.
adjective If someone behaves in a furtive way, they appear to be trying to hide what they are really doing. His furtive manner aroused our suspicion.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb furtively He looked around furtively before climbing through the window.

form.definition: noun Fury is wild or very strong anger. He shouted at us with fury. Stan went into a fury when he saw the damage to his car.

noun A fuse is a wire in an electric circuit that melts when there is a fault or when the current reaches an unsafe level, thus stopping the flow of electricity. When I turned on the heater, the lights went outI'd blown a fuse.
noun A fuse is also a part of a firework or bomb along which a spark moves before the firework or bomb explodes.
verb If two things fuse or are fused, they join together. The welder fused the metal sheets together at the edges. His financial interests have become fused with those of his employer.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun fusion The building plan is a fusion of new and old styles.

form.definition: noun If someone makes a fuss about something, they get too worried or excited about it. I'm only going away for a weekend so don't make such an awful fuss! Karen manages to organise things without fuss.
verb If someone fusses, they get too worried or excited about something. Stop fussingI can do it by myself! Tom always fusses over which restaurant to choose.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See fussy.

form.definition: adjective If you are fussy, you are extremely careful in choosing things or you are too concerned about unimportant things. Jim's not fussy about who cuts his hairhe even lets his friends do it. Our cat's rather fussyit won't eat canned food.
adjective If an action is described as futile, it is not successful or useful. It's futile to complain; he won't listen to you. The doctors made several futile attempts to save him.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun futility

form.definition: noun The future is the time that will come after the present, or the things that are going to happen then. We all wish you a very happy future together. You need to start saving for the future.
noun If something has a future, it is possible that it will succeed. They say there's no future in farming these days. She's very talented and has a bright future as an actor.
in future If you say that something will happen in future, you mean that it will happen from now on. Don't be late in future. In future we'll be making our own travel arrangements.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective future My future plans are still uncertain.

form.definition: noun In grammar, the future tense is used to refer to things that will happen after the present. In English, it is often marked by will, shall >or< going to before the verb, as in: I'll go if you will. Shall we see you next week? He's going to get hurt soon, if he's not careful.
noun Fuzz is a mass of soft, light hair or fibre. Most people don't like to eat peaches with the skin on because of the fuzz.
adjective Fuzzy hair is soft and curly.
adjective If something looks fuzzy, its shape or outline is blurred rather than distinct and clear. Could you adjust the TV? The picture's a bit fuzzy.
adjective If your thoughts are fuzzy, you are vague or confused. It was a long time ago and my memory of the events is rather fuzzy.[fa[xp
